content:
Posted: October 7, 2011
												 If you are tired of the usual genres and gameplay styles and want something new give this a go.  Yes, parkour is sooooo 2005, but it's really well done here: it's fast, fluid, and fun with just the right balance in player control required to keep the game from turning into ether a cumbersome and overcomplicated mess or an over simplified and tedious push-a-button-and-mindlessly-jump-from-roof-to-roof "Assassain's Creed" type experience.  The storyline isn't all that great (although it's kind of refreshing in its "run from the bad guys!" simplicity), but the graphics are still awesome 4 years later and the art design has a nice "Run Lola Run" meets "Blade Runner" aesthetic to it.    The game can get a bit too "trial and error" at times, but it's so short (I completed the entire thing in 4 hours my first time through) and it looks and plays so well that it really doesn't overstay its welcome.  It's the perfect game to get on sale for 5 dollars and waste an evening or so with.

content:
Posted: June 15, 2014
												Positives:-Gorgeous visuals, with colorful aesthetics, that escape from the boring greys and darks from typical urban environments in videogames.-Well implemented Parkour gameplay (the core aspect of the game), with decent physics and a nice flow of momevement and momentum. A breath of fresh air, on a market where all first person games are shooters by default.-Great soundtrack, that fits the visuals of each level (even for those who dont usually appreciate the subgenre of ambient music, like me).-Faith, the protagonist and best character in the game.Negatives:-The combat gameplay, felt a bit clunky and forced, i always preferred to run away form enemies.-The shooting gameplay is not very good, but it wasnt supposed to be anyway, with the option of not using firearms in all scenarios, and discarding the guns when done with them (this is a positive!).-The story and most secondary characters are, if not bad, at least, unremarkable, and the ending is too rushed (hopefully the sequel will provide more answers and some sense of achievement).Overall:Great, innovative game with fun, fluid (not so much on my crap PC) gameplay, with a short story but with a good amount of extra challenges, that add up to a nice length of entertainment. May Mirrors Edge 2 come quickly, and even better!

content:
Posted: May 3, 2014
												One of the most unique games you'll ever  play, albeit not without it's rough edges. Mirror's Edge fuses platforming and parkour in a first-person perspective. You'll do lots of climbing and running, and with the exception of a few problem areas, it's very easy to control your character. The visual design is an eye-catching mix of real and abstract, with lots of sterile white and heavily-saturated colors that help you quickly make your way along rooftops and through interior sections.The sound design and music are excellent. Objects whizz by your ears and you feel every scrape, slide, and impact. The music is dynamic, changing based on whether or not you are being pursued or what you're doing.That said, Mirror's Edge suffers from its own design. The level design is near-perfect at some times, but in other times the layouts are so damn confusing. Autosaves are well-placed, but it tends to rub salt in the would, especially considering how hard it is to make vertical distance as opposed to horizontal distance. The controls in the context of climbing or scaling things are either unresponsive or lead to unintended consequences.And to add to these occasional moments of frustration, the game boasts micro-sized gunfights and a few scripted fight sequences. These do a decent job of breaking the platforming, but they're frustrating in their own right. The gunplay feels very hollow and brings the speed and grace to a grinding halt. Normally you can run past your assailants, but a few times you will need to disarm them and slaughter every hostile in the area before you can continue. It feels incredibly shoehorned, half-baked, and I daresay it goes against the setting and the characters' nature. There are also two or three sequences where you need to fight or disarm someone as part of a cutscene, and these are not only frustrating, but they stop the game flow entirely.There's also the issue of the story. It's all over the place, and it rarely makes sense. She's something of a courier, but her higher-up has no qualm about her running around and trying to solve her own problems instead of actually doing her job. The game shuffles you around different areas and stories, hoping you won't realize it actually fleshes none of them out. The animated cutscenes are nice, but considering the game can be completed in an afternoon, there's nothing long-lasting about them. It's the kind of game that would benefit from a nicely-crafted story; unfortunately, you won't get that here.Despite all this, however, Mirror's Edge isn't a bad game. It shows hints of pure genius, and for the most part it's good. It's unique enough to stand out in almost every aspect, but the experience as a whole is kind of forgettable.

content:
Posted: January 8, 2015
												Mirror's Edge is a first person parkour game with platforming and shooter elements. The player takes control of Faith as she uncovers the plot of murder, into which her sister was framed.The graphics look amazing for its time, and stand out even today. Just like it's name suggests, the environments are shiny and often pure eye candy (if you like big cities or semi-futuristic rooms).The gameplay is very simple: you use your parkour skills to move from one location to the next, exploring new areas, forwarding the story, and sometimes fighting enemies. For movement, you can perform wallruns, walljumps, pull-ups, rolls, slides... overall, it feels like there is no obstacle you can't surmount. The game (on lower difficulties, at least) also supplies you with Runner Vision, coloring red every object that you can use to move forward. The controls, while not lacking in options, do feel kind of stiff however. Mostly because you see everything from first-person perspective and thus your vision is often obscured by some objects. Environmental awareness is the key to success. Also, one bad jump or trick can send you plummetting to your death (which is a quite realistic portrayal of how it feels to fall from 30-story building to your death), but whenever that happens, it's almost always your fault.Combat, however, tends to be frustrating. Considering a few bullets will put you down and you often fight several gun-wielders while unarmed, it's quite understandable that you'll be at a disadvantage. Even on Normal it's very easy to lose. However, it's not that bad once you get the hang of it and can also wield weapons taken from defeated enemies (you do only get one clip, tho). The game gives you pistols, submachine guns, machine guns, and even sniper rifles at some points of the game, so don't be afraid to use those.The game offers three main gamemodes: Story, Race and Speedrun. Story allows you to play through different chapters of the story mode, accompanied by comic book-style custscenes. This mode is however very short, taking only maybe five hours to complete, including retries due to frequent deaths. Race allows you to do time trials on various short sections of the game, after which the game rates your performance. Speedrun is unlocked after completing the game and is basically Race applied to whole chapters of the Story mode.Overall, this game is very well done, a bit short, but has a good replay value.

content:
Posted: January 7, 2016
												Mirror's Edge. Painfully tedious at times, too heavily reliant on guns, unimpressive combat.And yet, the best parkour game out there, probably. (Until ME: Catalyst comes out.)Worth buying if you like these kinds of games.Parkour was not a theme commonly used in games until recently. So when Mirror's Edge came out no doubt people would have been excited. And as a person that enjoys Titanfall, I think it's got the best first-person mobility on the market. (ME, not Titanfall, great game though it is.)But the fluidity came at a cost. I can't help but feel DICE tried too hard to make it part-FPS. The combat breaks the smooth free feel of the game, unless you just run away. They're fixing this in Catalyst, making the combat more parkour-based, which is only good news. So, that's another box ticked for fans of the game.One of ME's best qualities was that, in theory, most chapters could be beaten in one fluid run, without stopping. And it does a good job of replicating the adrenaline-filled leaps of faith that comes with rooftop running.And you can't help but admire the art style of the city. It's a beautiful landscape of white and red that can hardly be put into words. It has to be experienced.Except that you're kind of trapped in small areas in the levels. But, again, DICE is adressing this and giving Catalyst the open world that the original desperately needed.To summmarise:Good parkourBad mostly everything else, but that doesn't matterEasy on the eyes - very easyNeeds open world and better fighting (both happening, thanks DICE)Buy this if you can't be bothered to climb a building and jump off roofs yourself.I would have made this review humourous, but I just couldn't think of any jokes. Sorry, folks.

content:
Posted: January 12, 2016
												When it comes to gaming, it takes a lot to get me to actually finish a game. Usually I play a decent ways through, get bored, drop the game for a few months, and then if I try again I have to start from scratch because I don't remember what I'm doing. Mirror's Edge, however, broke the pattern: This game seriously captivated me start to finish and honestly I would've still been hooked if it went twice as long.You can't access hard mode until you've played through the game at one of the lower difficulties, so I went ahead and made it more challenging on my own by turning off Runner's Vision and refusing to shoot a gun. This was so much fun: Without Runner's Vision suddenly every room was not just an obstacle course but a puzzle where you had to figure out where exactly you can grab ledges or scurry up walls to get to the exit. And without grabbing a gun I got the satisfaction of punching a bunch of enemies in the face repeatedly, even if I died a lot because it's still "fists vs bullets" after all.The story left a bit to be desired in my opinion. The plot twists were rather predictable and I would've liked a little "hint of the future" at the end of the story rather than an abrupt "Welp, that sure happened." It keeps the story open-ended, certainly, but nevertheless it just felt unsatisfying. I also think it would've been good to have more red herrings about where you're supposed to go with additional pointless ramps or some such, but that might just be because my favorite part was the puzzle of not using Runner's Vision and I like challenging puzzles.All in all, this is a fantastic game that I heartily recommend. It feels so real without a visible health bar or constant background music that you will be suddenly convinced that jumping between buildings in real life is a good idea. I also heartily recommend turning off Runner's Vision especially for your first playthrough, since it makes things a lot more fun than just allowing the game to tell you where to go.

content:
Posted: December 7, 2014
												Mirror's Edge. Fast-paced action game all about momentum and using three buttons to do a million things. The game is set in a dystopian and overly uniform city of towering skyscrapers, and the plot revolves around the murder of a close friend of the main character's family. The game is essentially get to Point A to Point B, without dying, as fast as you can. Combat is rather awkward and there isn't much of a way to learn moves except trial and error, which can prove to be extremely irratating. Graphics reflect the dystopian world in solid, vivid colors, and keep the puzzles simpler as different key objects can be easily separated by the distinct colors. Voice acting is tolerable, but not especially impressive. As previously mentioned, momentum is imperative in performinfg many of the game's not-so-realistic moves, but oddly is often lost in solving some of the intermediately difficult puzzles. Overall, I would recommend this game.Graphics: simple yet uniquely beautiful. Gameplay: engaging, smooth and straightforward, although some moves are difficult to figure out. Story: not exactly gripping, but good enough for a parkour game.I would give it a confident 8/10 review.

content:
Posted: December 23, 2015
												I wish we could see more games like Mirror's Edge in the future. Mirror's Edge is not the usual first-person shooter or adventure game. Instead, it is a game highly focused on art. The buildings contain outstanding color schemes and the game always feels very bright. However, not only is the environment stunning but the score and Faith's movement are outstanding as well. The score is perfect. It adds so much to the game without drowning out the sounds of the city when you would expect to hear it. It was also very captivating at times that you would want it to be. Faith's movements feel very real and fluid. It is extremely satisfying to jump from a high place and hit the ground with a roll. The story in this game is quite good, but not the best. This is because I was overwhelmed by the fantastic score and eye candy building interiors.    Though this game is outstanding in almost every way, it also has its faults. I found it extremely difficult to memorize the controls. Certain actions, such as jumping, are mapped to an odd place on the controller (Left shoulder button). However, I don't see it being mapped any other way that would have made sense. The only other down side that I have noticed would be the rare glitch in the free running mechanics. This is expected because no video game is without a glitch or flaw somewhere. Overall, Mirror's edge is one of the best gaming experiences I have had in a long time. This is definitely one of my favorite games.  I see myself playing it in the future time, and time again.

Posted: April 29, 2014
												Did I like this game? Not at first, no. It took a while to like it. My main problem with it? Nvidia. PhysX is awful. Its broken. It doesn't work. I spent the longest time trying to get the game to stop lagging and to stop screen-tearing. I gave up for a couple months, and eventually came back. This time I figured out what was wrong. It was PhysX. So I enabled v-sync and disabled PhysX. BAM, suddenly the game runs perfectly. BUT when you finally get into the game, its great. The running is a bit awkward, parts of the running and stuff seem unrealistic, however on the whole, its pretty awesome. You get to run around and jump and vault and wall-run and more. What I wish they'd fix is the combat. Its okay, I guess, but when you're trying to disarm, its a 50/50 for whether you can actually do it. Most of the time you're a split-second late or early, and the soldier kills you. You can take a few shots, but it gets to the point later in the game where you're getting killed what seems to be WAY too easily, compared to earlier in the game. The story is great if you're paying attention. It could be a lot better, they should have revealed more about what happened to the City and how its come to this awful state its in now, but instead they set all the focus on saving Kate. Its not bad, because its still a pretty great story, but it could be better and more indepth. I figure Mirror's Edge 2 (if it ever gets released, and if DICE doesn't ♥♥♥♥ it up) will have all that backstory.

content:
Posted: November 27, 2013
												I enjoyed the time I had with Mirrors Edge. While it manages to pull of a beautifully fluent free running and combat system that tie greatly into the world, it does have its host of problems.The first thing I saw in Mirror's Edge was the controls. At first, I was hard on the idea that these controls sucked, and that they needed alot of tweaking. However, I learned quickly the game had a curve to it, and got passed the controls. When I finally got good at basic movements, I became absorbed in the world. The towering skyscrapers, colorful rooftops as well as the very dark secrets that were hid in this utopian masquerade. Cool right? Yes. However, it is really hard for me to appreciate the mythos of the game beyond its scenery, and beautiful scoring. This was because the story was god awful. Riddled with messy , sloppy, cheezy, and otherwise worthless dialouge, there was no way I was going to give two ♥♥♥♥♥ about the sister to sister relationship in the story. And to put the icing on the cake, I was utterly displeased with the ending. You will know when you get there. Completely disregarding the story, the freerunning in the game was spectacular. With many ways to run on rooftops and build up momentum, I was very much envigorated when I pulled off the perfect string of moves. The blur on the sides of the screen when momentum building is a very amazing feeling. Then came the combat. For reasons I can not understand, people hated the combat in the game. And I agree and disagree at the same time. While pulling off ninja moves on a guard was fitting for the missons, the gunplay was stale. This could have easily been avoided by making weapons more sleek and getting rid of the heavy guns. It really brought me out of all the agility in the game when I lugging around a huge♥♥♥♥♥M249. So for Mirrors Edge 2, please keep the gunplay; but make it exciting! Make me feel like a badass when I finally get the gun out of the guards hands and run away from the firefight.There is also one other problem in the game, and that was the Runner's Vision. While artisticly this was cool, I felt as a game mechanic I did not like this. However, this really comes down to personal preference. I personally thought Runner's Vision held my hand throughout the game, highlighting where I should go next. Being chased from rooftop to rooftop by guards is not very fun when you know exactly where to go - I want to have to think fast to move to my objective! This mechanic can only be turned off on the hardest difficulty too, which is a shame. However, this is totally up to you on what you want out of Mirror's Edge. To conclude, Mirrors Edge is a great game. Free running is a wonderful time, and stringing together the perfect combo is simply rewarding as hell. The combat, while it can be vastly improved, is a good concept. And Runner's Vision is totally up to personal prefrence. The world is spectacular too, really putting a "POW" into the scenery with all its spectacular and vibrant color, while appropiatley contrasting the darkness that lies within the utopian universe. I really wish I could care more for the politics in this game, but the story is just too boring and dull for me to care! Characters are generic and unexciting, not to mention the cutscenes look like an All State commercial. But overall, this game is a gem, and the parkour is hands down the best I have ever been able to experience.

content:
Posted: May 3, 2014
												One of the most unique games you'll ever  play, albeit not without it's rough edges. Mirror's Edge fuses platforming and parkour in a first-person perspective. You'll do lots of climbing and running, and with the exception of a few problem areas, it's very easy to control your character. The visual design is an eye-catching mix of real and abstract, with lots of sterile white and heavily-saturated colors that help you quickly make your way along rooftops and through interior sections.The sound design and music are excellent. Objects whizz by your ears and you feel every scrape, slide, and impact. The music is dynamic, changing based on whether or not you are being pursued or what you're doing.That said, Mirror's Edge suffers from its own design. The level design is near-perfect at some times, but in other times the layouts are so damn confusing. Autosaves are well-placed, but it tends to rub salt in the would, especially considering how hard it is to make vertical distance as opposed to horizontal distance. The controls in the context of climbing or scaling things are either unresponsive or lead to unintended consequences.And to add to these occasional moments of frustration, the game boasts micro-sized gunfights and a few scripted fight sequences. These do a decent job of breaking the platforming, but they're frustrating in their own right. The gunplay feels very hollow and brings the speed and grace to a grinding halt. Normally you can run past your assailants, but a few times you will need to disarm them and slaughter every hostile in the area before you can continue. It feels incredibly shoehorned, half-baked, and I daresay it goes against the setting and the characters' nature. There are also two or three sequences where you need to fight or disarm someone as part of a cutscene, and these are not only frustrating, but they stop the game flow entirely.There's also the issue of the story. It's all over the place, and it rarely makes sense. She's something of a courier, but her higher-up has no qualm about her running around and trying to solve her own problems instead of actually doing her job. The game shuffles you around different areas and stories, hoping you won't realize it actually fleshes none of them out. The animated cutscenes are nice, but considering the game can be completed in an afternoon, there's nothing long-lasting about them. It's the kind of game that would benefit from a nicely-crafted story; unfortunately, you won't get that here.Despite all this, however, Mirror's Edge isn't a bad game. It shows hints of pure genius, and for the most part it's good. It's unique enough to stand out in almost every aspect, but the experience as a whole is kind of forgettable.

content:
Posted: November 27, 2013
												I enjoyed the time I had with Mirrors Edge. While it manages to pull of a beautifully fluent free running and combat system that tie greatly into the world, it does have its host of problems.The first thing I saw in Mirror's Edge was the controls. At first, I was hard on the idea that these controls sucked, and that they needed alot of tweaking. However, I learned quickly the game had a curve to it, and got passed the controls. When I finally got good at basic movements, I became absorbed in the world. The towering skyscrapers, colorful rooftops as well as the very dark secrets that were hid in this utopian masquerade. Cool right? Yes. However, it is really hard for me to appreciate the mythos of the game beyond its scenery, and beautiful scoring. This was because the story was god awful. Riddled with messy , sloppy, cheezy, and otherwise worthless dialouge, there was no way I was going to give two ♥♥♥♥♥ about the sister to sister relationship in the story. And to put the icing on the cake, I was utterly displeased with the ending. You will know when you get there. Completely disregarding the story, the freerunning in the game was spectacular. With many ways to run on rooftops and build up momentum, I was very much envigorated when I pulled off the perfect string of moves. The blur on the sides of the screen when momentum building is a very amazing feeling. Then came the combat. For reasons I can not understand, people hated the combat in the game. And I agree and disagree at the same time. While pulling off ninja moves on a guard was fitting for the missons, the gunplay was stale. This could have easily been avoided by making weapons more sleek and getting rid of the heavy guns. It really brought me out of all the agility in the game when I lugging around a huge♥♥♥♥♥M249. So for Mirrors Edge 2, please keep the gunplay; but make it exciting! Make me feel like a badass when I finally get the gun out of the guards hands and run away from the firefight.There is also one other problem in the game, and that was the Runner's Vision. While artisticly this was cool, I felt as a game mechanic I did not like this. However, this really comes down to personal preference. I personally thought Runner's Vision held my hand throughout the game, highlighting where I should go next. Being chased from rooftop to rooftop by guards is not very fun when you know exactly where to go - I want to have to think fast to move to my objective! This mechanic can only be turned off on the hardest difficulty too, which is a shame. However, this is totally up to you on what you want out of Mirror's Edge. To conclude, Mirrors Edge is a great game. Free running is a wonderful time, and stringing together the perfect combo is simply rewarding as hell. The combat, while it can be vastly improved, is a good concept. And Runner's Vision is totally up to personal prefrence. The world is spectacular too, really putting a "POW" into the scenery with all its spectacular and vibrant color, while appropiatley contrasting the darkness that lies within the utopian universe. I really wish I could care more for the politics in this game, but the story is just too boring and dull for me to care! Characters are generic and unexciting, not to mention the cutscenes look like an All State commercial. But overall, this game is a gem, and the parkour is hands down the best I have ever been able to experience.

content:
Posted: January 21, 2014
												A parkour game mashed with first-person shooter elements. That is essentially what Mirror's Edge encompasses. Upon hearing about this game I was immediately excited and curious by the notion that it was different from many other 'first person shooters' I had previously played. The screenshots looked enticing and the trailer was amazing.Picking up during a Steam sale was perhaps one of the best purchases I have made on Steam.The game is exciting, fluid and dynamic. The mere feel of jumping over buildings in a huge, modern and visually striking city coupled with the stunningly real feeling of vertigo, is something unique to this game. The controls are excellent which give the feeling of power and strength that your character, Faith, encompasses. This along with the stunning graphics, which scaled remarkably well on mid-range hardware (i7 3630qm, GT 740m), being still able to run on 'highest' on full resolution; are just a couple of the reasons why this game is rather excellent. (I recommend turning off the crosshair and HUD. This increases the feeling of immersion)For all these good points however, there are some negatives. This game is not perfect. The story is rather short and forgettable, revolving around some sort of political conspiracy; and I felt the cartoon-like cutscenes clashed with the photorealistic nature of the rest of the game, pulling me out of the immersion. Several stages were also poorly designed which left me dying repeatedly until I managed to accomplish a semi-impossible feat (I'm looking at you last level). But this could have perhaps been due to my incompetence at the game itself...When taken as a whole however, Mirror's Edge is amazing, which leaves me eagerly anticipating its second instalment.

content:
Posted: December 26, 2014
												I honestly don't know where to begin, other than saying that this is a great game. And I truely mean it. With a compelling story, fascinating and yet unique gameplay, and georgeous level design, this game forms a true masterpiece.While the story certainly isn't  BioShock-level great (no, I'm not comparing this game to BioShock), it's not bad either. You play as a runner (the "protagonists" of the story), Faith, and save her sister after she's been accused of murder. Nothing to fancy. Unless you've complete the game, however, but I'm not going to spoil it. The story also is a bit short, I managed to complete it in 4 and a half hours, and that was on my first run through it. Story - 7/10The graphics some will say aren't the best, and I can see that. But I think that the game looks spectacular when running at the highest settings. Brilliant use of color, especially an uncommonly used color in games these days, white. The lighting helps too, however, it proved to be a bit annoying in some levels, but that's okay as you can turn the brightness down if you wish. The levels mainly consist of rooftops, and sometimes inside a building. However, you will also explore the inside of a storm drain, alleyways, and a harbor. I did think that it was a bit linear - at first it seems like pathways branch, and they do, but only in certain segments of a level. (Example, you're on a rooftop, and there is a gate. There are multiple ways to get around the gate, but once you do get around it, lies behind it a ramp you're to spring off of.)  Level deisgn/graphics - 8/10While the gameplay may look quirky in videos, and actually may seem quirky when learning them for the first time, believe me, they're not. You'll get used to them right away, and just like the game's purpose, you'll flow smoothly right through the stages. The game isn't that difficult, but some levels can be. You also can use guns, which was actually going to be a bigger element of gameplay in earlier versions, it really isn't that big. They work like normal guns, should - they shoot.  But honestly, they didn't feel needed, if it weren't for how many cops the game throws at you in certain levels. But like I said before, the game's intenion is to flow through the levels. They want the gameplay to become a natural thing. And I think they achieved that.Gameplay - 9/10Mirror's Edge is a wonderful, exhilerating action-platformer that requires some skill. While things may look different through a video, the game will suck you in and drop you into a whole new world of flow and colors. I think it is completely worth the $20 it charges, though if a sale is coming quite soon, I reccomend waiting as you won't be missing much. Final verdict - 8/10

content:
Posted: December 29, 2013
												A beautiful game with a very distinct art style. While in the actual game you're in a 3D environment, the story parts are in 2D, in style reminiscent of a graphic novel.Gameplay can become quite frustrating at times, as timing is extremely important. You might find youself repeating the same part of the level literally dozens of times. After the first three levels though, you should probably understand how to solve most of the problems.The tutorial, while going very in-depth and showing you practically every move you might need in-game, feeds you all the information in one five-minute session. If you're not one of those people that remember every combination of keystrokes right away, you might find yourself in a pinch not knowing what to do when faced with certain obstacles (going from personal experience: by forgetting I had the ability to double tap space while wall running, I added probably one or two hours of gameplay and frustration to my first playthrough). But once you get the hang of the controls and figure out the different ways you can use your surroundings to move around, most of the levels become a breeze.While the story, in terms of development, is pretty predictable, there's a few aspects that make it (and the whole game) stand out. For one, the main character is a woman of Asian descent, who instead of being driven by some kind of romantic nonsense, is trying to save her sister. No one makes a deal about her being a woman, no one even acknowledges it. She's not special because of it. She's just another runner. And that is really great, in my opinion.In conclussion: after two hours of head-bashing against the keyboard trying to understand the controls, it quite quickly jumped to one of my top 10 games of all time. The recently announced Mirror's Edge 2 is definitely on my watch list.

content:
Posted: May 3, 2014
												One of the most unique games you'll ever  play, albeit not without it's rough edges. Mirror's Edge fuses platforming and parkour in a first-person perspective. You'll do lots of climbing and running, and with the exception of a few problem areas, it's very easy to control your character. The visual design is an eye-catching mix of real and abstract, with lots of sterile white and heavily-saturated colors that help you quickly make your way along rooftops and through interior sections.The sound design and music are excellent. Objects whizz by your ears and you feel every scrape, slide, and impact. The music is dynamic, changing based on whether or not you are being pursued or what you're doing.That said, Mirror's Edge suffers from its own design. The level design is near-perfect at some times, but in other times the layouts are so damn confusing. Autosaves are well-placed, but it tends to rub salt in the would, especially considering how hard it is to make vertical distance as opposed to horizontal distance. The controls in the context of climbing or scaling things are either unresponsive or lead to unintended consequences.And to add to these occasional moments of frustration, the game boasts micro-sized gunfights and a few scripted fight sequences. These do a decent job of breaking the platforming, but they're frustrating in their own right. The gunplay feels very hollow and brings the speed and grace to a grinding halt. Normally you can run past your assailants, but a few times you will need to disarm them and slaughter every hostile in the area before you can continue. It feels incredibly shoehorned, half-baked, and I daresay it goes against the setting and the characters' nature. There are also two or three sequences where you need to fight or disarm someone as part of a cutscene, and these are not only frustrating, but they stop the game flow entirely.There's also the issue of the story. It's all over the place, and it rarely makes sense. She's something of a courier, but her higher-up has no qualm about her running around and trying to solve her own problems instead of actually doing her job. The game shuffles you around different areas and stories, hoping you won't realize it actually fleshes none of them out. The animated cutscenes are nice, but considering the game can be completed in an afternoon, there's nothing long-lasting about them. It's the kind of game that would benefit from a nicely-crafted story; unfortunately, you won't get that here.Despite all this, however, Mirror's Edge isn't a bad game. It shows hints of pure genius, and for the most part it's good. It's unique enough to stand out in almost every aspect, but the experience as a whole is kind of forgettable.

Posted: March 7, 2014
												In Mirror's Edge, you can choose to either play aggressively or passively. The whole fun of the game (and the obvious core) is running around and doing parkour in possibly one of the most beautiful cities you could ever parkour in (and clean). For a game released in 2009, it's more than what you could ask for (visually/aesthetically talking). The clean, peaceful and safe feeling that the environment around you provides is simply amazing (which is funny seeing how sometimes you might be running for your life). Even though the overall game is visually stunning, some of the levels (again, visually speaking) will just keep you speechless (causing my deaths several times in several levels, but..."IT WAS TOTALLY WORTH IT."The game itself, well. Some levels you will find incredibly frustrating and nearly impossible at times, but that's actually a good thing, or a pro about the game. The reason behind this is, because once you manage to accomplish the level, the satisfaction and the sense of accomplishment (and lets admit, cleverness) is beyond satisfying. Cons? Well, my top recommendation is to disable physx. That is basically the killer of the game. It can cause severe (and I mean SEVERE) frame issues and lag, even going as far as crashing your game. I'd also recommend avoiding confrontation when faced against many cops or snipers (oh how I despise those snipers).Oh and, you'll find out what I mean when I say that you should probably RUN FOR YOUR LIFE when you're being chased by your shadows (or runner's shadows, not quite a spoiler. As you probably don't have a clue of what I'm taking about).If you're having problems in deciding if the game is worth it or not, I guarantee it, if you love parkour and stunning visuals, go for it. I'd also recommend it so you get to know the origin of Mirror's Edge (as the second one will be coming out eventually).What are you waiting for, buy the game!

												8/10: Mirror's Edge is a very cool game. I thought I'd better try it out since Mirror's Edge 2 will be coming out, and I'm sure glad I did. Mirror's Edge offers a really unique and entertaining form of gameplay with its free-running mechanics and a beautiful world with vibrant colors to enjoy them in. The story isn't amazing, but it works well with the gameplay. The gunplay/combat is pretty poor (though you can pull off a pretty sweet dropkick), and I wish you had the option of simply avoiding fighting altogether, so you could focus on the aspect of the game that really shines: its core mechanics. Running, jumping, and navigating the city feels extremely satisfying, and the game presents you with many exciting environments to test your parkour skills. The chase scenes in particular can be quite exhilarating. There are some moments of frustration and minor annoying details, but overall the free-running system is done very well. There is also definitely some good replay value as there are time trials, and the main story could easily be enjoyed for multiple playthroughs. I will definitely be looking forward to the sequel.

content:
Posted: December 21, 2013
												Mirror's Edge is an extremely enjoyable game that provides great freedom to the player in regards to speed.This game is a first person game where you are able to run as fast as you can to get to point A to point B. And it does not disappoint in doing so. You can climb over many obstacles, gaining momentum as you zip through your mission. Speed matters in this game, and Mirror's Edge does a good job at bringing parkouring to life. You can jump to buildings, climb on pipes, wall run across billboards, and sprint your way to the goal. There is so much you can do in regards to running and the adrenaline you get from it is amazing. There are not a lot of games out there that solely focus on freerunning (InMomentum and the Assassin's Creed series only come to mind to me) but this game harbors a great experience. The story is neat, and you can enjoy some time trials to beat your old times or top others. There are some puzzles in the game that you have to go through, but it's what makes the runner experience just as fun.There are some issues that I would like to point out. The story is short. I was disappointed when the game had ended to early, and would like it if they added more to the mix. The combat system could have been improved as well. In some instances in the game you would resort to killing your enemies via gun or hand-to-hand combat. The gun mechanics are okay but lack the ability to aim down the sight (but that shouldn't matter since this isn't an first person shooter). The close quarters combat is really clunky with only one animation to combo some punches and a kick to knock your enemy down. Fighting in this game wasn't really satisfying, but it didn't ruin the experience for me. I had more fun sprinting freely through obstacles than punching guys who sometimes are not worth fighting.I hightly recommend this to those who love freerunning and a fast paced adventure game. Mirror's Edge brings up a nice take to a type of game that has not been touched upon in a while.

content:
Posted: April 21, 2015
												Mirror's Edge is a fantastically presented mediocre game.While its visual style, music, and atmosphere are top-notch, its core gameplay is, in my opinion, slightly lacking. While the game shines in its free-running segments, pretty much every part of the game where you're being shot at feels like a chore. And these segments are unfortunately numerous.The main theme of the game is free-running, and the first advice you're given about combat is "avoid the enemy". Naturally, the best option in a game like this, where your character, Faith, is extremely agile and quick, is to run from the enemy, evade them, or sneak by them. However, stealth is impossible; enemies will simply detect you no matter how much care you take to sneak quietly. Additionally, there are many forced combat segments: the game tells you to avoid the enemy, then places you in situations where you are unable to do so. This wouldn't be a problem if the combat were enjoyable, but unfortunately, I did not enjoy it.The main flaw with the combat is the lack of a learning curve. On Normal mode, enemies can shoot you dead in two or three hits. This means that there is no time for Faith to practice her moves; if she messes up at all, which is inevitable when practicing, she's dead, and you have to start the whole sequence over again. Reaction time does little to remedy this. These segments really throw a wrench in the otherwise smooth action of Mirror's Edge.As I said, the game is very smooth, and its free-running segments, where your only enemy is a steep drop off a roof, are stellar. It feels very rewarding to get the hang of the controls and totally ace a segment without falling or losing momentum. Unfortunately, these segments are mostly used as links between the combat segments in the later game. I feel as though Dice, a developer probably best known for its shooters, felt they needed to incorporate shooter elements here in abundance. But the game would be much better off if it revolved more around the parkour elements, with combat being optional.Enough about the combat, let's talk about the better parts of this game: The design is fantastic. The use of strong color and good use of visual filters makes this game look like a work of art. The cartoon cutscenes between chapters are great, if slightly low-budget feeling (many frames are noticably re-used). The music is great, and helps the peaceful sections feel peaceful and the dangerous sections feel tense. The characters, while not explored terribly much, still play their parts well, and putting yourself in Faith's shoes is not hard. The unlockables are a nice touch as well.Despite its flaws, this game is still solid. But now that I've experienced it first-hand, I wouldn't say it's as great as many people say it is. When I find myself admiring the aesthetics and theme of a game more than its actual gameplay, it's hard for me to recommend it to others. However, if you can get this game on sale, I would recommend you play through it simply for the experience. It's presented very well, and it's a shame it didn't have more dev time (there are some cut things in the unlockables), and it's also a shame that it was so short. Hopefully the sequel can improve on this game's flaws, but as it stands, I'd only recommend it at a reduced price.Good Points:- Stunning visual design, amazing aesthetics- Good free-running segments, Runner Vision is an intuitive system- Good music that bolsters the atmosphere- Engaging charactersFlaws:- Forced combat segments feel out-of-place- Lack of learning curve, no real way to practice combat- Too little free-running for a game that's supposed to revolve around it, compared to gunplay and combat- Pretty short, no expansions or extra story content - Stealth is impossible, enemy AI is telepathicBottom Line: It's a great work of art, but only a passable game. Recommended, but only if it's on sale.

content:
Posted: June 28, 2016
Product received for free
												I got this game through family sharing. So, I didn't pay for it, but it wasn't given to me by EA or anything. It was still paid for, just not by me.First off, I've wanted to play this for years, but couldn't. Either the splash screen showed up and went away and that was it, or it just plain didn't do anything except start the process for a bit. The solution? Move one file up a folder. (It's got its own folder within the folder it should be in, and it won't work with the way it's set up when you install it. Don't know how whatever update did that got sent out, or why it's not fixed. ALL YOU HAVE TO DO IS MOVE ONE FILE UP A FOLDER, EA.)Then I had to shut off PhysX because it's apparently an old version that don't work so good or something, and I would get major FPS drops when glass shattered. That means glass breaking doesn't look as nice, but it's better than playing a slideshow of still images.Now, to the actual game after fixing all problems. Was super excited. Its story is okay, and supposedly Catalyst is better when it comes to story, but I haven't played it yet. It's just kind of "Here's a reason to go to this place. WOOP, HERE ARE THE COPS, BETTER RUN!" It's sorta interesting, but definitely follows that pattern most of the time. The gameplay is good and I honestly think those who say combat "breaks the flow" should be quiet. You can jump, kick them in the face, and go past while they're stunned, or you can have a good time stealing people's weapons and clearing the room to make your escape. It's a grab-a-gun-shoot-gun-throw-gun-away sort of thing. Sort of like SUPERHOT; the enemies have infinite ammo, but you have a limited amount and a basic cop's gun isn't going to take down an entire room full of heavily-armed and well-armored private guards. I think combat was relatively well-executed for a game not focused on it and fits well. My only problem is that the guards that chase you and are really difficult to fight are hard to fight partially because it seems like when you both do the same thing, their attacks take priority and only you take damage when you both should. I know, they're supposed to be the near-unstoppable force that you need a gun or serious skill to defeat, but I feel like they're a little broken in just how unbeatable they are. It's like two people punching eachother in the chest and only one getting hurt because the other's the stronger of the two. They only show up in like, three places in the game (though in two there's no guns around to shoot them with) so they're no big deal. At first, I thought combat was simple. Grab dude's gun, shoot his buddies, move on, but there's a suprising number of weapons, four or five.Now, to actually talk about the freerunning. It's great. It's the kind of system I wish every game had. It feels almost exactly like it should, except the three times out of a hundred that you jump sideways, or wallrun vertically instead of horizontally (or vice versa). That and the fact that you seem to not stretch your arms out all the way to grab stuff sometimes are my only problems. The bar is right there, Faith. Just grab the bar. Just reach out, and grab the bar. Nope, okay, go plummeting to the ground and lose track of the person you're chasing. That's fine too. Oh, I have to wallrun up and bounce off the wall. Didn't know that got you higher than just jumping. (This was like halfway through the game that I learned this.) Thanks for reading to this point, by the way. I know I talk a lot. Anyways, it just feels great just because you go fast and it's the smoothest movement system I've seen, really. Works really well.It's a pretty game. It even makes ventilation ducts look nice, at least in the final area. The gold lighting is great. The game mostly follows a white-and-bright-color scheme, say, white and orange or white and green. Most interactable things are red, and the secrets are bright, glowing orange, obviously visible once you get to where they are, which I didn't always. There's always an indicator that there's one about, though, if you care to look. I'm pretty sure that the colors were thought about to some extent for almost every area. Nothing looks plain, not even the white rooftops. There's always a splash of color visible somewhere, it seems.I loved this game and wish there was more. I hope Catalyst is longer, because I'm probably going to buy it at some point.

content:
Posted: June 11, 2016
												I orignially played this game a couple of years ago on a friends Xbox and it was really frustrating because of my awful controller skills. Then I got it a couple of years back and it was just standing in my library. In the last couple of days I realised that I haven't really played a full game in a long time so I installed and started my runner journey. The tutorial was basic stuff and I really liked the mechanics and combos you can do with the walls and jumping on enemies. It felt great, the different routes you could do was quite fun, because the game didn't feel linear. Still it should've been more open, with side quests, different factions, discovering the city, helping other people or something like that, only that was lacking. But again the game was quite fun. Picking up guns was not my style, I only used the guns when there were a lot of enemies. The A.I. was quite good, it actually made me think twice before jumping on more of them, because they kill me fast. Hell, it has better A.I. then most games today. I had problems in some areas because when you jump on the red ledge it does not always work, but maybe it's just me. A couple of times I got stuck in the wall, or got slowed by an invisible bump. The enemies glich and start going bat♥♥♥♥♥♥crazy when I kick them in the ground, but that happened about 3 times in the whole game. It's quite a fast game, if you don't make any mistakes you can finish it in about 4 hours, but if you are like me it takes a bit more. Sometimes I thought I needed to backtrack when I get away from enemies and die, until I realise I just have to go forward. The story was pretty good, but it wasn't all that clear. I felt like it needed more explanation (Yeah, I know I can go on the Wiki and find everything I need to know, but that's not the point). The animations were not that bad, but not that good either. They were a bit messy, if more effort was put into them, the cutscenes would've been so much better.Do I recommend it? Absolutely, if you like the parkour type games, you will enjoy it a lot. How would I rate it? 9/10, it's great, but some things are still missing, I pointed it all out.

content:
Posted: May 28, 2014
												Mirror's Edge was released in 2007 as one of the first Frostbite Engine games, as a proof-of-concept of sorts. You play as Faith, a runner (messenger) in a futuristic city that can't seem to decide whether it's in America or Asia, with signs displaying both English words and characters. The color scheme is amazing, and the way lighting and textures are handled, I probably would've guessed it was released in 2010 or 2011 based on how good it looks. Faith gets through the city using parkour moves, with the game focusing more on acrobatics than combat mechanics. Running, jumping, sliding, and the other moves feel fluid and not at all nausea-inducing, but fighting is reduced to mashing buttons and hoping you don't die. There are only 3 types of guns, which you pick up off police officers and drop when ammo is gone, but gunplay is minimal in the game. This is encouraged by not being able to do any sort of parkour while holding a gun. I found myself only using Runner Vision (slow-mo) when I really needed to, though mostly just to make long jumps look really cool. I did also find myself accidentally triggering it fairly often. Bugs are rare, having encountered only 2 or 3 in the many times I've played it.TL;DR - Looks great, but you need a higher-end GPU. Parkour is great, combat not so much. Overall fun, and more should be expected from 2015 (?) sequel. More should be revealed E3 2014.

content:
Posted: February 1, 2015
												There are two mechanics of this game that are implemented with varying amounts of success.First: the parkour. This is the thing this game was made for. Faith runs like a dream, and there's nothing more satisfying than flying across rooftops and making those jumps that would probably break a normal person's legs. When this game is going fast, it's great.Second: the combat. Where do I even start with this? First of all, the game encourages you to avoid combat as often as possible. After all, you're playing a fragile speedster, so when it comes to fight or flight, flight is the better option. That being said, the game often doesnt LET you avoid combat. There'll be too many people shooting at you, and even with all your running and ducking and dodging chances are you'll be gunned down in seconds. And again, you're a fragile speedster, emphasis on the fragile part. You can't take very many hits. So when running isn't an option (even though the game will remind you that you SHOULDN'T be fighting), the only other choice you have is to fight. So what's the problem with fighting? Try: most everything. The timing for disarming someone is absurdly anal (and chances are while you're doing that someone else will be shooting you in the back), the timing for striking is anal (most often they'll just block and you'll be knocked back instead), and the controls for attacking someone while moving are awkward. If you engage in hand to hand, expect to have to repeat a segment over, and over, and over.In other words, every time combat happens, the game comes to a grinding halt. The point of the game is to be going fast and getting from place to place quickly and adeptly, but this becomes impossible when you have to slow down to fight 10 heavily armed guards that just rushed you and cut off the only escape route that doesn't end with a sickening *splat* sound. Combat completely throws off the pacing. The game tries to make the combat faster paced by causing the action to start the moment you enter a room, but this leaves no window of time for you to adjust to the surroundings. I get that part of the game is being able to react and choose routes quickly and everything, but there's only so fast a human can react before they get shot.(And I'll add here that you could just grab a gun and use that, but there's this little notice on the pause menu that tracks if you've shot anyone yet, and though I haven't finished the game yet, I can figure it'll be important. If this doesn't bother you, go for it. The game's great.)For all my complaining, though, I really do like this game and would recommend it, or at least the parkour parts. The combat system is poorly managed (and IMO doesn't belong in this type of game), but it isn't impossible, just incredibly frustrating. My grievances with the combat system are meant to be more of a forewarning than a dissuasion. Mechanics aside, the story, art, and voicing are fantastic, so design in that sense is solid.TL:DR; play it, it's great, but either brace yourself for grueling combat sequences or stuff your morality and use a gun.

content:
Posted: October 7, 2011
												 If you are tired of the usual genres and gameplay styles and want something new give this a go.  Yes, parkour is sooooo 2005, but it's really well done here: it's fast, fluid, and fun with just the right balance in player control required to keep the game from turning into ether a cumbersome and overcomplicated mess or an over simplified and tedious push-a-button-and-mindlessly-jump-from-roof-to-roof "Assassain's Creed" type experience.  The storyline isn't all that great (although it's kind of refreshing in its "run from the bad guys!" simplicity), but the graphics are still awesome 4 years later and the art design has a nice "Run Lola Run" meets "Blade Runner" aesthetic to it.    The game can get a bit too "trial and error" at times, but it's so short (I completed the entire thing in 4 hours my first time through) and it looks and plays so well that it really doesn't overstay its welcome.  It's the perfect game to get on sale for 5 dollars and waste an evening or so with.

content:
Posted: January 9, 2015
												A race for time, or a waste of time?Mirror's Edge takes something that many of us wish we were fit enough to do, and makes it into a core gameplay mechanic for anyone to enjoy. Is it fun? Yes! Absolutely! But it's not as groundbreaking as some hoped it would be (someone like me :P).It's a good game with some designer flaws, none of which, however, deter from the experience. Allow me to elaborate.In this game you play as a runner named Faith (how quaint) who runs into a, well, let's call it a "political disagreement" with the local PD, giving her (and you) an excuse jump off walls, off buildings, off TRAINS! Basically there is a lot of stuff to jump off of. And on, as well, as you are given the ability to beat the crap out of your enemies using said running and jumping abilities. This is very a smooth combat system, and very entertaining to do, as using your momentum to drive your punches and kicks like a projectile leaves you with an awesome feeling. The game seems to suffer from some kind of split personality disorder, though, as it can't tell if it wants to be a freerunning racing game, or another stylish EA shooter (meh). There are several points in the game where the only way to progress is to pick up a gun and blast/snipe your way through. Luckily there are only a few parts like these. The game markets itself as something unique and different that the current FPS generation would enjoy, however if you ignore running aspect and focus on what else the game is offering you basically have a linear campaign with several elements taken from games such as Half-Life 1+2 and portal, such as having to analyze your surroundings and cleverly use them to your advantage (another would be crawling through the air vents). This doesn't necessarily make this a bad game, just don't expect it to be ground breaking. I thought I was going to have an experience similar to Prince of Persia, but really it was far from it. It's a game of speed and momentum, where you are trying to get from point A to point B in the smoothest and quickest way possible, whereas Prince is about using special climbing techniques to solve puzzles that take up entire rooms.The graphics are great, and the massive city truely looks amazing. The Unreal 3 engine really shines in this game. I just wish we could actually go into the city and explore it more. Instead you are guided through a linear path, probably because that way it could tell the story, however unrelatable it was. It's clear that they worked hard on the story, but it's just so convoluted that I found myself paying less and less attention to it as I went along. The gameplay keeps you more engaged than the story, which is ok.I personally liked it, and found myself coming back to the time trials to kill some time. Without a doubt this game had much more potential, and with the fact that they had to revise the story several times, it kinda shows. But for a new IP with an experimental play style it seemed to present itself quite well. I would recommend this game to people who want to kill a weekend with some high velocity scissor kicks and clever outside-the-box speed run levels.

content:
Posted: November 27, 2013
												I enjoyed the time I had with Mirrors Edge. While it manages to pull of a beautifully fluent free running and combat system that tie greatly into the world, it does have its host of problems.The first thing I saw in Mirror's Edge was the controls. At first, I was hard on the idea that these controls sucked, and that they needed alot of tweaking. However, I learned quickly the game had a curve to it, and got passed the controls. When I finally got good at basic movements, I became absorbed in the world. The towering skyscrapers, colorful rooftops as well as the very dark secrets that were hid in this utopian masquerade. Cool right? Yes. However, it is really hard for me to appreciate the mythos of the game beyond its scenery, and beautiful scoring. This was because the story was god awful. Riddled with messy , sloppy, cheezy, and otherwise worthless dialouge, there was no way I was going to give two ♥♥♥♥♥ about the sister to sister relationship in the story. And to put the icing on the cake, I was utterly displeased with the ending. You will know when you get there. Completely disregarding the story, the freerunning in the game was spectacular. With many ways to run on rooftops and build up momentum, I was very much envigorated when I pulled off the perfect string of moves. The blur on the sides of the screen when momentum building is a very amazing feeling. Then came the combat. For reasons I can not understand, people hated the combat in the game. And I agree and disagree at the same time. While pulling off ninja moves on a guard was fitting for the missons, the gunplay was stale. This could have easily been avoided by making weapons more sleek and getting rid of the heavy guns. It really brought me out of all the agility in the game when I lugging around a huge♥♥♥♥♥M249. So for Mirrors Edge 2, please keep the gunplay; but make it exciting! Make me feel like a badass when I finally get the gun out of the guards hands and run away from the firefight.There is also one other problem in the game, and that was the Runner's Vision. While artisticly this was cool, I felt as a game mechanic I did not like this. However, this really comes down to personal preference. I personally thought Runner's Vision held my hand throughout the game, highlighting where I should go next. Being chased from rooftop to rooftop by guards is not very fun when you know exactly where to go - I want to have to think fast to move to my objective! This mechanic can only be turned off on the hardest difficulty too, which is a shame. However, this is totally up to you on what you want out of Mirror's Edge. To conclude, Mirrors Edge is a great game. Free running is a wonderful time, and stringing together the perfect combo is simply rewarding as hell. The combat, while it can be vastly improved, is a good concept. And Runner's Vision is totally up to personal prefrence. The world is spectacular too, really putting a "POW" into the scenery with all its spectacular and vibrant color, while appropiatley contrasting the darkness that lies within the utopian universe. I really wish I could care more for the politics in this game, but the story is just too boring and dull for me to care! Characters are generic and unexciting, not to mention the cutscenes look like an All State commercial. But overall, this game is a gem, and the parkour is hands down the best I have ever been able to experience.

content:
Posted: January 21, 2014
												Mirror's Edge has done something not many games do. It combined visuals and gameplay into such a unique experience that you cannot find in much games. Mirror's Edge takes the term 'parkour' to such an extreme level. You're literally traveling from building to building. With your FEET. The only other game I can think of that takes free-running to such an extent would be Assassin's Creed, only first-person and modern. The visuals, thankfully made with the Frostbite engine, are spectacular. Especially if you have the right PC setup. The style is amazing, with the mostly white metropolis brightly lighting up objectives and significant building with color-schemes for every level. Not only are you running from enemies, but you have to fight them too. In most situations, you choose between fight or flight. Stealth is an option, but a hard one. After taking out an enemy, you can pick up their weapon and use it against your enemies. The thing is, there is no ammo count; you only use the ammo in the clip and discard the gun. This enthuses players to go the traditional parkour gameplay of the game. The game is not that long, since I beat it in a short 4-hour session. But it has decent replayability, being encouraged to try to beat your time throughout the levels. The story... is pretty dull. I won't talk about the story, but it's a bit cliche. For the price, I think this game is definitely worth buying, with its original gameplay and concepts that you can't really get anywhere else.

content:
Posted: January 21, 2014
												A parkour game mashed with first-person shooter elements. That is essentially what Mirror's Edge encompasses. Upon hearing about this game I was immediately excited and curious by the notion that it was different from many other 'first person shooters' I had previously played. The screenshots looked enticing and the trailer was amazing.Picking up during a Steam sale was perhaps one of the best purchases I have made on Steam.The game is exciting, fluid and dynamic. The mere feel of jumping over buildings in a huge, modern and visually striking city coupled with the stunningly real feeling of vertigo, is something unique to this game. The controls are excellent which give the feeling of power and strength that your character, Faith, encompasses. This along with the stunning graphics, which scaled remarkably well on mid-range hardware (i7 3630qm, GT 740m), being still able to run on 'highest' on full resolution; are just a couple of the reasons why this game is rather excellent. (I recommend turning off the crosshair and HUD. This increases the feeling of immersion)For all these good points however, there are some negatives. This game is not perfect. The story is rather short and forgettable, revolving around some sort of political conspiracy; and I felt the cartoon-like cutscenes clashed with the photorealistic nature of the rest of the game, pulling me out of the immersion. Several stages were also poorly designed which left me dying repeatedly until I managed to accomplish a semi-impossible feat (I'm looking at you last level). But this could have perhaps been due to my incompetence at the game itself...When taken as a whole however, Mirror's Edge is amazing, which leaves me eagerly anticipating its second instalment.

content:
Posted: February 1, 2015
												There are two mechanics of this game that are implemented with varying amounts of success.First: the parkour. This is the thing this game was made for. Faith runs like a dream, and there's nothing more satisfying than flying across rooftops and making those jumps that would probably break a normal person's legs. When this game is going fast, it's great.Second: the combat. Where do I even start with this? First of all, the game encourages you to avoid combat as often as possible. After all, you're playing a fragile speedster, so when it comes to fight or flight, flight is the better option. That being said, the game often doesnt LET you avoid combat. There'll be too many people shooting at you, and even with all your running and ducking and dodging chances are you'll be gunned down in seconds. And again, you're a fragile speedster, emphasis on the fragile part. You can't take very many hits. So when running isn't an option (even though the game will remind you that you SHOULDN'T be fighting), the only other choice you have is to fight. So what's the problem with fighting? Try: most everything. The timing for disarming someone is absurdly anal (and chances are while you're doing that someone else will be shooting you in the back), the timing for striking is anal (most often they'll just block and you'll be knocked back instead), and the controls for attacking someone while moving are awkward. If you engage in hand to hand, expect to have to repeat a segment over, and over, and over.In other words, every time combat happens, the game comes to a grinding halt. The point of the game is to be going fast and getting from place to place quickly and adeptly, but this becomes impossible when you have to slow down to fight 10 heavily armed guards that just rushed you and cut off the only escape route that doesn't end with a sickening *splat* sound. Combat completely throws off the pacing. The game tries to make the combat faster paced by causing the action to start the moment you enter a room, but this leaves no window of time for you to adjust to the surroundings. I get that part of the game is being able to react and choose routes quickly and everything, but there's only so fast a human can react before they get shot.(And I'll add here that you could just grab a gun and use that, but there's this little notice on the pause menu that tracks if you've shot anyone yet, and though I haven't finished the game yet, I can figure it'll be important. If this doesn't bother you, go for it. The game's great.)For all my complaining, though, I really do like this game and would recommend it, or at least the parkour parts. The combat system is poorly managed (and IMO doesn't belong in this type of game), but it isn't impossible, just incredibly frustrating. My grievances with the combat system are meant to be more of a forewarning than a dissuasion. Mechanics aside, the story, art, and voicing are fantastic, so design in that sense is solid.TL:DR; play it, it's great, but either brace yourself for grueling combat sequences or stuff your morality and use a gun.

content:
Posted: January 8, 2015
												Mirror's Edge is a first person parkour game with platforming and shooter elements. The player takes control of Faith as she uncovers the plot of murder, into which her sister was framed.The graphics look amazing for its time, and stand out even today. Just like it's name suggests, the environments are shiny and often pure eye candy (if you like big cities or semi-futuristic rooms).The gameplay is very simple: you use your parkour skills to move from one location to the next, exploring new areas, forwarding the story, and sometimes fighting enemies. For movement, you can perform wallruns, walljumps, pull-ups, rolls, slides... overall, it feels like there is no obstacle you can't surmount. The game (on lower difficulties, at least) also supplies you with Runner Vision, coloring red every object that you can use to move forward. The controls, while not lacking in options, do feel kind of stiff however. Mostly because you see everything from first-person perspective and thus your vision is often obscured by some objects. Environmental awareness is the key to success. Also, one bad jump or trick can send you plummetting to your death (which is a quite realistic portrayal of how it feels to fall from 30-story building to your death), but whenever that happens, it's almost always your fault.Combat, however, tends to be frustrating. Considering a few bullets will put you down and you often fight several gun-wielders while unarmed, it's quite understandable that you'll be at a disadvantage. Even on Normal it's very easy to lose. However, it's not that bad once you get the hang of it and can also wield weapons taken from defeated enemies (you do only get one clip, tho). The game gives you pistols, submachine guns, machine guns, and even sniper rifles at some points of the game, so don't be afraid to use those.The game offers three main gamemodes: Story, Race and Speedrun. Story allows you to play through different chapters of the story mode, accompanied by comic book-style custscenes. This mode is however very short, taking only maybe five hours to complete, including retries due to frequent deaths. Race allows you to do time trials on various short sections of the game, after which the game rates your performance. Speedrun is unlocked after completing the game and is basically Race applied to whole chapters of the Story mode.Overall, this game is very well done, a bit short, but has a good replay value.

content:
Posted: January 7, 2016
												Mirror's Edge. Painfully tedious at times, too heavily reliant on guns, unimpressive combat.And yet, the best parkour game out there, probably. (Until ME: Catalyst comes out.)Worth buying if you like these kinds of games.Parkour was not a theme commonly used in games until recently. So when Mirror's Edge came out no doubt people would have been excited. And as a person that enjoys Titanfall, I think it's got the best first-person mobility on the market. (ME, not Titanfall, great game though it is.)But the fluidity came at a cost. I can't help but feel DICE tried too hard to make it part-FPS. The combat breaks the smooth free feel of the game, unless you just run away. They're fixing this in Catalyst, making the combat more parkour-based, which is only good news. So, that's another box ticked for fans of the game.One of ME's best qualities was that, in theory, most chapters could be beaten in one fluid run, without stopping. And it does a good job of replicating the adrenaline-filled leaps of faith that comes with rooftop running.And you can't help but admire the art style of the city. It's a beautiful landscape of white and red that can hardly be put into words. It has to be experienced.Except that you're kind of trapped in small areas in the levels. But, again, DICE is adressing this and giving Catalyst the open world that the original desperately needed.To summmarise:Good parkourBad mostly everything else, but that doesn't matterEasy on the eyes - very easyNeeds open world and better fighting (both happening, thanks DICE)Buy this if you can't be bothered to climb a building and jump off roofs yourself.I would have made this review humourous, but I just couldn't think of any jokes. Sorry, folks.

Posted: December 23, 2015
												I wish we could see more games like Mirror's Edge in the future. Mirror's Edge is not the usual first-person shooter or adventure game. Instead, it is a game highly focused on art. The buildings contain outstanding color schemes and the game always feels very bright. However, not only is the environment stunning but the score and Faith's movement are outstanding as well. The score is perfect. It adds so much to the game without drowning out the sounds of the city when you would expect to hear it. It was also very captivating at times that you would want it to be. Faith's movements feel very real and fluid. It is extremely satisfying to jump from a high place and hit the ground with a roll. The story in this game is quite good, but not the best. This is because I was overwhelmed by the fantastic score and eye candy building interiors.    Though this game is outstanding in almost every way, it also has its faults. I found it extremely difficult to memorize the controls. Certain actions, such as jumping, are mapped to an odd place on the controller (Left shoulder button). However, I don't see it being mapped any other way that would have made sense. The only other down side that I have noticed would be the rare glitch in the free running mechanics. This is expected because no video game is without a glitch or flaw somewhere. Overall, Mirror's edge is one of the best gaming experiences I have had in a long time. This is definitely one of my favorite games.  I see myself playing it in the future time, and time again.

content:
Posted: July 2, 2016
												I dont do very many reviews, in fact I have to be truly impressed with a game or thoroughly dislike one to even bother.Mirrors Edge has landed on truly impressed. The citywide graphics are refreshingly bright and crisp, where most rpg graphics tend to be dark and sinister this brings a really nice feel of realism to the game. The only issue I had with framerate was when a lot of bullets are flying and cops are chasing Faith the impact of the particle system slowed them down a touch. My system can handle them but just to be sure I lowered the settings and lost very little of the detail and none of the beauty of the game and the framerate never wavered. The CG cutscenes are very well done and fall into the action with seamless ease. I personally would have liked to see more of these and a bit less of the cartoon styled ones, but thats just a matter of preference and takes nothing away from the story. The story thus far is well written and nicely voice acted, emersing you into the game and keeping you hungry to see what happens next. The combination of eyecandy graphics and great storyline are what has impressed me the most. I cant wait to see if they truly do make a Mirror's Edge movie and will absolutely want a copy. This brings me to gameplay, which takes some timing skill and plays out a lot like a 3D platform game might, with Faith running the rooftops for her life, jumping and sliding, in parkour style movements that have to be perfectly timed to keep her from falling to certain injury or death. Dont expect to fight your way out of most situations. Yes she has some skills but this isnt a female Rambo. She fights only when she has to. Which for myself only makes it seem more realistic and challenging. Albeit the story line is a bit linear the game does have a race mode and challenges that give it some replay value, and hours of story game play that will keep you coming back. Not many games can hold my attention enough to make me forget time. But it was easy for me to sit down here thinking I'll play for an hour and go to bed , only to look at the clock four hours later and wonder where the time went. Addictive, emersive gaming, I absolutely reccomend this to anyone looking for something new and exciting to play.

Posted: February 14, 2016
												Oh my god. I love this game and I hate it. The structure is sections of really, really satisfying first-person parkour broken up by awful sections where you'll die to a bunch of dudes with guns over and over. I don't know if I've ever played a game with such a huge gap between my best and worst experiences: at its best, its levels are designed like puzzles you need to solve with the handful of techniques you're taught (for better or worse) at the start of the game. At its worst, you're thrown into a big room with a bunch of boxes and heavily-armed guys, and given no sense of where to go or whether to fight. (Pressing the Alt key is supposed to direct your view toward your goal, but that's not always the case.)The joy of running, the visual design, and the world-building are all good enough, in my opinion, to still make this a game worth playing. I just wish I could give an unqualified recommendation.
