content:
Posted: April 21, 2015
												Mirror's Edge is a fantastically presented mediocre game.While its visual style, music, and atmosphere are top-notch, its core gameplay is, in my opinion, slightly lacking. While the game shines in its free-running segments, pretty much every part of the game where you're being shot at feels like a chore. And these segments are unfortunately numerous.The main theme of the game is free-running, and the first advice you're given about combat is "avoid the enemy". Naturally, the best option in a game like this, where your character, Faith, is extremely agile and quick, is to run from the enemy, evade them, or sneak by them. However, stealth is impossible; enemies will simply detect you no matter how much care you take to sneak quietly. Additionally, there are many forced combat segments: the game tells you to avoid the enemy, then places you in situations where you are unable to do so. This wouldn't be a problem if the combat were enjoyable, but unfortunately, I did not enjoy it.The main flaw with the combat is the lack of a learning curve. On Normal mode, enemies can shoot you dead in two or three hits. This means that there is no time for Faith to practice her moves; if she messes up at all, which is inevitable when practicing, she's dead, and you have to start the whole sequence over again. Reaction time does little to remedy this. These segments really throw a wrench in the otherwise smooth action of Mirror's Edge.As I said, the game is very smooth, and its free-running segments, where your only enemy is a steep drop off a roof, are stellar. It feels very rewarding to get the hang of the controls and totally ace a segment without falling or losing momentum. Unfortunately, these segments are mostly used as links between the combat segments in the later game. I feel as though Dice, a developer probably best known for its shooters, felt they needed to incorporate shooter elements here in abundance. But the game would be much better off if it revolved more around the parkour elements, with combat being optional.Enough about the combat, let's talk about the better parts of this game: The design is fantastic. The use of strong color and good use of visual filters makes this game look like a work of art. The cartoon cutscenes between chapters are great, if slightly low-budget feeling (many frames are noticably re-used). The music is great, and helps the peaceful sections feel peaceful and the dangerous sections feel tense. The characters, while not explored terribly much, still play their parts well, and putting yourself in Faith's shoes is not hard. The unlockables are a nice touch as well.Despite its flaws, this game is still solid. But now that I've experienced it first-hand, I wouldn't say it's as great as many people say it is. When I find myself admiring the aesthetics and theme of a game more than its actual gameplay, it's hard for me to recommend it to others. However, if you can get this game on sale, I would recommend you play through it simply for the experience. It's presented very well, and it's a shame it didn't have more dev time (there are some cut things in the unlockables), and it's also a shame that it was so short. Hopefully the sequel can improve on this game's flaws, but as it stands, I'd only recommend it at a reduced price.Good Points:- Stunning visual design, amazing aesthetics- Good free-running segments, Runner Vision is an intuitive system- Good music that bolsters the atmosphere- Engaging charactersFlaws:- Forced combat segments feel out-of-place- Lack of learning curve, no real way to practice combat- Too little free-running for a game that's supposed to revolve around it, compared to gunplay and combat- Pretty short, no expansions or extra story content - Stealth is impossible, enemy AI is telepathicBottom Line: It's a great work of art, but only a passable game. Recommended, but only if it's on sale.

content:
Posted: September 17, 2014
												The selling point of 'Mirror's Edge' is the gameplay -- that is the parkour-inspired platforming in the first-person perspective. There was nothing like it at the time of the game's release, and there is nothing like it now at the time of this review. There is a story in 'Mirror's Edge', but it is not that interesting and is merely there to move the action along. As a fan of good stories in video games, I can overlook that because the first-person platforming is fun, albeit much, much trial and error is needed to complete a level most of the time.The game's clean, bright visuals are refreshing given the predominantly dark, brownish, shadowy looks of contemporary first-person shooters. The look of the game makes the gaming experience uplifting, which is much needed when you get frustrated from falling to your death many times in the game. There is an in-game system called "Runner Vision" that highlights environmental elements that are useful in solving the platforming puzzles, but those elements can still be hard to see as you may be in fast motion at the time. In later parts of the game, objects are highlighted less and less.The game is plagued with strange technical flaws that are hard to overlook though. First, if the PhysX option is turned on, it will cause debilitating drops in framerates if you are not using an nVidia GPU. (It should have been disabled automatically.) Second, you can't change a game's video settings mid-game and you will need to quit your current game to do so. Lastly, the checkpoints where you resume your game can vary, seemingly based on whether you are in the same game session (e.g. after an in-game death) or you are continuing a previously saved game (e.g. you start the game and click "Continue Game"). That means you may find yourself playing a level all over again just because you decided to quit the game mid-level. More frequent checkpoint saves would have been nice.At the time of this review, I have not played the game for over three months. I have uninstalled it even though I have not finished it because there is just not enough good points to lure me back for more. (Ironically in short, I have lost my momentum with the game.) Despite its flaws, I am still recommending 'Mirror's Edge', but not as enthusiastically as I had for games like 'Dishonored' and the 'Tomb Raider' reboot. There is much to improve on to make 'Mirror's Edge' an even better game, but what we have here is good enough to experience at a discount price.

												I had heard of this game a lot when it came up, I had seen the trailers for it a long time ago, the awesome anime-ish style trailers and seen very small amounts of gameplay. Let me tell you, I have only (At the time of me writing this review) played about 25 minutes. Already love this game. FIrst off, I was happy how my crappy PC ran this game so smoothly, Secondly, I LOVE How your character Faith Feels, her movements are so fluid, like water, so agile and graceful. I freaking LOVE IT. And it needs to be all these things in order to play the game. The game it'self is more of a puzle game slightly portal-esque, Minus portal, Why it reminds me of portal is because it uses the enviroment as the puzzles, I freaking love that. There are so many ways to move, like making yourself smaller in mid air so you can hop over barbed wire fences, Zipline, slide, climb, shimmy, sidestep, wall ride, roll to save yourself from taking damage. You literally FEEL LIKE A RUNNER. You feel like a legitimate bada$$. I highly recommend this game, even if you may have a slightly laggy computer, this game will run beautifully for you. SOOOO worth the money, even though I got this game on sale for 5 bucks, It's sooo worth more! But I have more money to spend on other games as well >.>

content:
Posted: April 18, 2014
Short Version+ great art design+ parcour running feels fantastic- highly frustrating fights- here and there problems with controls not reacting as expectedGame supports 360 controller and I recommend using it.Long VersionThis game could be awesome. But it has two serious problems. Let's start with the really great sides of Mirror's Edge. The art design is just astonishing. The looks of the city with their different color themes, the asia touch and the fitting music create an interesting futuristic scenario. These components established the same feeling which I had in Deus Ex: HR before. If you played it you will know what I mean. Also the parcour running is just pure fun. When you are able to chain multiple moves in a fast run you feel SO good! If the game would feature parcour runs only, it would probably one of my favourite games of all time. BUT the game also is higly frustrating. There are several sequences where you have to fight armed policemen. And it is possibly the most horrible thing I have ever experienced. You will die. You will die so often. And that is not all, it will also feel unfair. You know this feeling when you think you are doing the best the game has to offer and you still die almost randomly? At one point I even thought about quitting completely. Another con is that the controls are sometimes not precise. If you played the old Tomb Raider games you will remember deaths because you jumped 5 degrees in the wrong direction. Overall the controls are good, don't get me wrong, but I had several moments where I definitely pressed the right button in the right moment and still somehow fell down or the character didn't grab the ledge.Nevertheless if you are interested in the game you should grab it for this price. The good sides of it are worth experiencing the frustrating ones. In reflection I feel positive about Mirror's Edge. And from my personal point of view everyone who is interested in video games in general should know this title.You should also use a 360 Controller, the game even supports it.

												Dude its the best! a new type of genre game that came out in 2008...it was revolutionary. I still do play it from time to time (installing this and uninstalling it seems like a bother now) but it's one of my top 10 games and I am looking forward for Mirror's Edge 2 as it seems to deliver a worthy sequel from the trailers (wouldn't know until the game is released and played). One thing I loved is the music score they used in this game (especially Chapter 9 Kate and the beginning score used in the Shard); an absolute masterpiece! I just stared in the sky during start of the Shard and seeing that airplane flying across the atmosphere (contrails) and the night time office buildings around it, reminds me of my hometown (quite literally infact, and also hosted a clean, sterile environment but to the extremes like bleaching trees white and free-style police is of that world). These kind of scenes made me happy and think of hope for reasons that I remembered back in my childhood (my dad would take me to his office in his work if he has to work late night and just staring out in the big window from his desk, seeing the aesthics of city properties with post-modern lamp posts and the office lights of other buildings adjacent to where I am)...its the best sight and memory to keep forever. The beauty of Urban landscaping at its best.But the one that topped everything off with cherry on top was the MAIN MENU ANMATION and the menu music complemented each other perfectly...I've been trying to find out how they made such graciful animation from and my conclusions lead to Autodesk, 3DS Max, or Maya but I am not sure and emailed countless times to DICE Sweden but like any other video game company, they always don't respond.I hope Mirror's Edge 2 would have equal or greater standards for their Main Menu Animation (love the city-scaping motion) and of course the Music Score has to be top-notch.

Posted: June 30, 2015
												The most common words out of your mouth when playing a game probably shouldn't be "oh for ♥♥♥♥'s sake". And yet...Yeah you don't need me to tell you what every other bad review has told you over the years but so thought I when I got this in the sale. I should preface by saying I really wanted to enjoy it, I mean really really wanted too but by the end, I was mad enough having spend £3 on it I'd've probably been been spitting if I spent ten. The sheer number of times you'll imagine your environment is built for a certain action and instead it will end with you plummeting to the street below is unreal. Say what you will of Assassin's Creed, at least it only tends to throw you to your death if you take a flying leap. Mirror's Edge will fling you off a ledge like an infant sacrifice if you sneeze while pressing left. Part of this is cos its so linear; you must Do The Thing in a timely manner or you will be getting aquainted with the floor super-quick. My only hope for people who play the sequel is that by then the dev team has fully worked up the environment and you can just fanny about in a giant playground should you so wish. My wishlist also follows; you have a circle of vision greater than the 45 degrees of wall you are facing when hanging from it; your only options when hitting a bloke isn't a one-two punch before getting rammed in the teeth with the butt of a rifle.In fairness, the story's alright, bit short but not awful. Non-descript villains who haven't really done something awful  except be ordered to stop the murder suspect, but who I'm going to shoot in the face anayway etc. I'd imagine you get more story -and feel like less of an♥♥♥♥♥ if you bother finding the runner's cases, since over the whole 7 hours I was playing I only came across five (I eschewed actually looking for them in favour of ending the farce as quick a possible) and at number five got a random burst of history lesson/moral patter from Faith that gave me V for Vendetta flashbacks. But again I didn't walk that road. Faith herself? Bit of a cow. By that logic she and I should get on, but instead I felt slightly more justified about the numerous times I would purposely hurl her off buildings -usually after another Stupid Death(TM)- just to hear all her bones go crunch when she met the pavement. That doesn't reflect well on me however so moving on.Its pretty too, I'll give it that. Although don't play in a dark room cos otherwise it ramps up from pretty to retina searing, say goodbye to a few colour receptors, because they will be inevitably BURNED AWAY.So if you want first person parkour I'd wait for the sequel to see if they've ironed out what didn't work. I can also imagine a few years down the line, after turning the saturation down (like to a dog's level of colour appreciation) playing this on Oculus Rift, cos THAT would make FPP fun, even if it will leave me in a puddle of my own sick.

												Hmm... Where to start?You should definitely buy Mirror's Edge, and here's whyMirror's edge gives you a unique free run experience. You can even run on the wall!Though the story is short, it's definitely interesting. I completed the game in 7 hours, but it might take you longer as you die quite a lot. The enemies in this game make it way harder to complete a part of a level. They kick you, and shoot at you. The graphics are great for its time, you could compare it to some games from now! What isn't that great is the fps cap, but with a small change in the files, it will run at as high as your graphics card allows it to.Let's talk about the levels for a second. The levels get harder and harder as you progress. Which sometimes makes it frustrating, and some people may ragequit. Though you'll have to use the same skills over and over again, the levels aren't boring. Everytime you start a level, you're in a completely different location. Sometimes you're at ground level, and sometimes on the roofs. The red textures indicate where you have to go, though sometimes you might get stuck as sometimes they're located too far from eachother. You'll just have to keep on looking for them.Mirror's Edge Catalyst will be out in 2016. If you can't wait for that one, then just play this one!

content:
Posted: September 2, 2014
												Skip to bottom for key points.This game was straight up awesome.  Once you take the time to learn the controls and develop some rudimentary skills, the fun factor goes way up.  The most fun part of the game for me was the time trials, because it's just pure parkour all over the place.  You get to make the rooftops your own, and run/jump/climb all over your territory.  The campaign itself is quite good.  The writing isn't great, and the plot unfolds somewhat predictably, but that was never the main focus of the game.  The focus is running from the cops, or chasing other dudes, and that's where all the excitement is.  There is a ton of adrenaline value in most of the levels, and the non-chase puzzle levels are so interesting, you're still on the edge of your seat.  A lot of the enjoyment of the game comes from how good everything looks.  It's a bit unrealistic that everywhere you go is so clean and amazing looking, but that just adds to the experience, and helps to remove anything that might distract you while you run full speed past it all.  The only downside to the campaign is that once you've really hit your stride and parkour through the levels like lighting, it ends up being over rather quick, leaving you wanting more.  Then it's time to challenge yourself and run it all again, looking for quicker runs, and more efficient paths.  There's such a good selection of path options, that it really encourages you to make split second decisions, and judgement calls.  If you do get hung up, and decide to fight it out with the pursuers, there's a pretty interesting and engaging combat system.  *Spoilers*  The cops constantly try to kill you and never hesitate to open fire.  Shooting them is fun, but you don't get much ammo so if you go exterminator mode like I did, you have to plan out your attacks and work your way from enemy to enemy one at a time.  Fighting one enemy is really fun.  Fighting two gives you about a 50% survival chance but it's still doable and still fun if you pull it off.  It's understandably not fun to get mowed down from 3 or 4 different directions if you just run into the fray, and that's what happens, so you have to stay tactical.  *More SPOILERS*  The ninja dudes at the end are hard as hell to beat, but they are killable, and I figured out to beat the sh** out of those mofos, but again it involves extreme tactics.  They, like you, regenerate unless hit a lot of times in quick succession.  Get 3 good hits on them in under 10 seconds and you knock them the heck out, but that's so hard to pull off it's easier to just run away and escape them.  Just to summarizePros:  Fun CampaignFun extra modesAwesome concepts and executionCool main characterLevels look coolParkour looks awesome and sounds awesome (the sound clips used are perfect)Can play like a speed demon or a vengeful punisherCons:Campaign is short if you speed demon the whole thingStory is probably the least developed part of the game.How much fun you have depends on how well you learn the system and timing.I spent a lot of time on the levels, finding shortcuts, killing everything, and exploring, so I got a lot out of the game.  It's unique and it draws you in.  Immersive yet light on a heavy gamer's pallete.  I'd even say, it's an almost perfect game.  5/5 stars.

content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												7 out of 10.  I'm giving it a thumbs-up because the free-running gameplay is an interesting mechanic, but the game has enough faults that I really only recommend it when you can find it on sale.All in all not a very good game, even though it seems to have a pretty rabid fan base. To be fair, the graphics are very good, especially considering it's a few years old, and the developers had some innovative ideas for how to play the game. Unfortunately actually playing the game just wasn't as fun as it should have been. Mostly the game suffers from pretty bad controls coupled with unforgiving gameplay mechanics, which results in having to replay sections over and over again. Most jumps and grabs have to be precisely timed and the distance precisely judged, but many times the button presses didn't register quickly enough, and it's in general pretty difficult to judge distances, so I found myself dying dozens of times when I missed jumps by no more than an inch or two - that got frustrating really fast. The control issue also raised its ugly head in the wholly mediocre combat. Many, many times the right-mouse button counterattack failed, which got me killed more times than I could count. I eventually grew to hate the combat so much that I just pounded on the first guard I saw, took his gun, then shot everyone else just to get it over with.The other huge frustration with the game was the fact that for such a completely linear game it was often nearly impossible to figure out where to go. There was supposed to be a hint system that highlighted your path in red, but sometimes it showed up off in the distance, sometimes not until you were right on top of the path, and sometimes not at all - I wandered around a lot because of that. Even worse was the level where the devs decided to paint everything in the building red; I don't know why, I guess maybe they just thought it was funny to frustrate us even further.To make matters even worse (or perhaps better, as things turned out) - beyond the spotty controls, oft-failing hint system, unforgiving mechanics and mediocre combat, the game took me all of 5 hours and change to complete. I'm not necessarily opposed to short games, as long as the story is engaging and gameplay is fun - The Darkness II is a perfect example. But this game was neither engaging nor more than moderately fun, and was far too short for the money they normally charge. Luckily I got this as part of the EA Humble Bundle, so I really didn't shell anything out for it. If you can pick it up really cheap then it's fine to waste time on for a few hours, but anything more than a few bucks is probably a waste of your money.

content:
Posted: December 22, 2012
												Mirror's Edge can be described in one word, and only one word really seems to fit. "Unique". Everything from the visual style of a bleached white city (which is hardly as boring to look at as it sounds) to the gameplay are some thing that I've never seen before, and am sad I haven't.The gameplay is hard to explain, and fits no real genre. "First person parkour shooter puzzle game" is probably the closest. When you reach that point in the game where you play flawlessly, able to launch over and under any obstacle you see it's something that feels... right.Combat is somewhat important, but most encounters can be avoided. Moving into combat comes as seamlessly as moving through parts of the level, and you can bring the same momentum and speed you feel in the parkour elements right into the battles.That's not to say the game is *all* gameplay. The story is also interesting, and the comic book style cutscenes do a great job portraying every important character in the game.It's not the world's longest game, but it's got immense replay value. Time trials, and the satisfaction of nailing each section with perfect landings and non stop running kept brining me back to the game.I recommend this game to fans of puzzle games (searching for paths to objectives up and down buildings and rooftops), and action game fans (because of the hectic movement and combat) alike. Every element seems to fall into place together, and it makes this a true classic that every fan of gaming should own a copy of.

												Mirror's Edge is an FPS set in a big city where Runners transport sensitive data across the city whilst avoiding the opposing forces of the law. Instead of relying on weapons, the theme in this game is set on outrunning your enemies. While the game is a bit dated, it is still a highly appreciated classic found in almost every common Steam user's library.PROS:+ Great freerunning adventure+ Nice and colourful graphics+ Fluent movement control+ Built-in speedrun option+ Replay value due remembering the paths and being able to do it fasterCONS:- The story is somewhat shallow- Sometimes the game focusses on a tricky jump rather than a parcour- Finding out where to go can be a little irritating at timesMy rating: 8/10

												Hmm... Where to start?You should definitely buy Mirror's Edge, and here's whyMirror's edge gives you a unique free run experience. You can even run on the wall!Though the story is short, it's definitely interesting. I completed the game in 7 hours, but it might take you longer as you die quite a lot. The enemies in this game make it way harder to complete a part of a level. They kick you, and shoot at you. The graphics are great for its time, you could compare it to some games from now! The levels get harder and harder as you progress. Which sometimes makes it frustrating, and some people may ragequit. Though you'll have to use the same skills over and over again, the levels aren't boring. Everytime you start a level, you're in a completely different location. Sometimes you're at ground level, and sometimes on the roofs. The red textures indicate where you have to go, though sometimes you might get stuck as sometimes they're located too far from eachother. 												Mirrors Edge is one of my favourite games (I used to own it on Xbox and recently bought it on Steam) as it has a pretty good story, great atmosphere, amazing fluidity and action. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 24, 2015
												I bought this game really wanting to love it. The concept of parkour and run-and-gun gameplay sounds great on paper, but its execution in Mirror's Edge is questionable. The story is boring and the voice acting, while not the most dreadful I've heard, is still pretty bland. The ending was incredibly rushed and there was practically no substance or depth throughout the plot.The parkour mechanics work and do pump some adrenaline in your gaming veins (I also have a phobia of heights, so it was kinda fun in that sense). There are moments where Faith will unexpectedly not grab ledges (where your margin to grab onto one is pretty reasonable) and you will end up raging quite a bit when Faith will jump to a pipe but not grab it because you're SLIGHTLY off-centered. The game isn't broken per se, but it could've used a lot more work in regards to parkour fluidity and ledge detection.The enemy AI is incredibly dumb and unfair. All the "blues" do is charge towards you with a constant set of bullets, and snipers have 110% accuracy, even when you're in mid-air. The parry system works half the time since when enemies try to hit you it's always hard to see if the gun turns red (prompt to parry and take the gun). Headshots deal the same amount of damage as a shot to the torso. There is also ZERO variation in enemies. You can argue that they have different weapons and abilities but they all the feel the same; they're all male (except for that one exception), they all have guns, and they all charge towards you.The story is painfully predictable. Every "twist" I witnessed, I expected early on (the antagonists have the stereotypical "this is how the world works bla bla bla" attitude). Also, the game takes four hours to complete on NORMAL. The other hour I spent playing was me trying to escape the train section, which was absolutely pointless and unrewardingly difficult.BUT I did have fun with this game. The main parkour sections are well laid out and I did enjoy using different tactics to take down enemies. The visuals are refreshing and the environments feel very open (albeit a little repetitive). The textures are appropriately saturated and detailed.I can only give this game a maximum of 6 out of 10, and can only recommend Mirror's Edge to people who don't mind trying retracing their steps multiple times. I am looking forward to Mirror's Edge Catalyst, hoping some of my issues with this installment will be fixed for the sequel.

												I really love the gameplay in mirror’s edge. There is never a dull or boring moment throughout the 4 hour long game, it keeps a steady pace the whole time. I can see people not liking the game much on console because a gamepad is just not as precise and quicker than the mouse and keyboard controls which is a big reason why I love the game on pc is because the mouse and keyboard are so responsive for this kind of game. So many memorable and awesome scripted moments like jumping from the crane, sliding down a building, riding on top of a train etc. The level design is so well done, it creates a great environment for you to free run across both indoor and outdoor. A big complaint I hear is the combat but I personally love it. I always got in the rhythm of disarming the first guy I see and using his gun to take out the others and I really enjoyed the brief moments I got to use a gun it was so much fun. The graphics, art style and soundtrack is all amazing. The only thing that keeps it from being a masterpiece is the story and characters. Both boring and uninteresting to say the least. Luckily it’s not a very big focus of the game. 9/10 (Amazing)

content:
Posted: December 24, 2015
												I bought this game really wanting to love it. The concept of parkour and run-and-gun gameplay sounds great on paper, but its execution in Mirror's Edge is questionable. The story is boring and the voice acting, while not the most dreadful I've heard, is still pretty bland. The ending was incredibly rushed and there was practically no substance or depth throughout the plot.The parkour mechanics work and do pump some adrenaline in your gaming veins (I also have a phobia of heights, so it was kinda fun in that sense). There are moments where Faith will unexpectedly not grab ledges (where your margin to grab onto one is pretty reasonable) and you will end up raging quite a bit when Faith will jump to a pipe but not grab it because you're SLIGHTLY off-centered. The game isn't broken per se, but it could've used a lot more work in regards to parkour fluidity and ledge detection.The enemy AI is incredibly dumb and unfair. All the "blues" do is charge towards you with a constant set of bullets, and snipers have 110% accuracy, even when you're in mid-air. The parry system works half the time since when enemies try to hit you it's always hard to see if the gun turns red (prompt to parry and take the gun). Headshots deal the same amount of damage as a shot to the torso. There is also ZERO variation in enemies. You can argue that they have different weapons and abilities but they all the feel the same; they're all male (except for that one exception), they all have guns, and they all charge towards you.The story is painfully predictable. Every "twist" I witnessed, I expected early on (the antagonists have the stereotypical "this is how the world works bla bla bla" attitude). Also, the game takes four hours to complete on NORMAL. The other hour I spent playing was me trying to escape the train section, which was absolutely pointless and unrewardingly difficult.BUT I did have fun with this game. The main parkour sections are well laid out and I did enjoy using different tactics to take down enemies. The visuals are refreshing and the environments feel very open (albeit a little repetitive). The textures are appropriately saturated and detailed.I can only give this game a maximum of 6 out of 10, and can only recommend Mirror's Edge to people who don't mind trying retracing their steps multiple times. I am looking forward to Mirror's Edge Catalyst, hoping some of my issues with this installment will be fixed for the sequel.

content:
Posted: January 1, 2016
												I've played this game many times, beaten it just as much too (only if Faith was acting up ;) ), not once got bored.However it seemed the more that I played it, the less focussed I was in getting to the ending. Instead I just runned around, jumped on and off things, trying to find hidden, secret places and spots where you just weren't suppossed to be.All in all this game was fun.Pros:------ Great graphics, the fact that there mainly are 3 prevailing colors (white, red and blue) just give it an unique feel- Intense moments, when jumping from building to building not trying to fall face first onto the pavement 30stories    below always gets my heart going- Not action oriented, I know some games that are the same yet are filled with action like you're suppossed to be some kind of surgeon yet you have to kill a bunch of aliens everytime you go to work. This game doesn't Faith isn't a fighter and even though you can partipate in the action, it usually is better if you don't because you will have to retry several times.- Nice open feel. Again I know a lot of games that claim to have the same yet you are kept on a short leash the entire time. Here you can but not always, goof around, trying to find the obscure runner bags which I still haven't found all of. But I remember this one time when some freak glitch happened and I had managed to get on street level, some weird...things happen down there.- Fluent control. Well at least most of the times, sometimes you'll run so fast and nail that perfect jump with the even more perfect landing. While other times, you'll get fried on some electric fences or take the one-way-express-elevator down. But working on your ingame parcour skills is what's most fun, doing all your moves in superspeed and getting from A to B in the quickest and most dangerous way possibleBut no game is perfectCons:------- Confusing level design. Or maybe it's only me, but first time playing it I got stuck a lot. Didn't know where to go, sometimes I could spent up to an hour searching for where I was suppossed to go, other times there was an added pressure because I was being chased by a lot of guys with guns. I only had my feet...they are not faster than a hailstorm of bullets. When I haven't played it in a year I forget I run in the same problems, only they don't take as long anymore.- Restrictions. Yes what I said earlier about open feel is still true, yet it isn't open world or sandbox. But it should've been, you can goof around as much as you like but you can't go further than the game lets you each level. You still have to go from A to B, how you do is up to you.- Action. Must be a first for me where I actually think the action is kinda...forced, phoned in. Don't get me wrong, the action is fun, but this isn't an FPS. So therefor it shouldn't feel like one, there are some moments in the game when you are forced to pick up a gun and shoot someone. Like I said earlier, Faith isn't a fighter yet she can use 9mms, shotguns, sniper rifles and heavy machine guns all with deadly accuracy. But you will run slower with a gun and you can't mount objects either, you can I supposse avoid most if not all combat situations but for me it shouldn't even have been in there.- Difficulty. This game can be pretty hard, but my point is actually at a more personal level. I don't expect that anyone agrees with me over this it's just me. I don't like the fact that in a higher difficulty setting 'Runner Vision' gets turned off. For those that don't know, any object you can use to get to your objective becomes red. This is the games way of saying, you need to use this. I understand without this vision the game becomes harder but for me not seeing splashes of red in a sea of whiteness destroys the entire game's feel. I really like the abscenes of most colors, everytime you see any other color it looks a bit odd because of it. But in the end this won't affect the scoring in anyway.- Length. This game is too short! It's really short, you'll have fun, you'll get stuck, you'll be back on your way and then it's done.Would I recommend this? Yes of course, if you actually had read any of it you wouldn't even be asking.Overall score I'd give it an 8/10 for being a great game, in this world where they are but a few.

												I do not know any other parkour games than this one. So i can not make any comparisons and i may not be objective. But i will try.Mirrors edge was a ground braking game back when it was released. A brand new concept for its time. So i think even if the story is cliche and short (4 hours is enough tom complete) and police is heroicly good at shooting and you are feeling puzzled more than a runner, the game deserves a recommended vote. You can challenge online people if you can find. Or race with their ghosts. Game is not much optimized but not the worst either.So i recommend this game because it was aground braking idea. But you can wait for the sequal too. Remember the story is 4 hours long and it is not only about running. Most of the time, running for your life.

												This is my new favorite power-fantasy game.  It's not an objectively good game, but just from personal taste, I love it.  It really goes all-out with the first person view, most immersive I've seen without a VR headset.  I've always wanted a game where I can walljump or roll in first person, and now I have it!  Faith's acrobatics *feel* more powerful than pretty much any shoot-em-up or stab-em-up, it's simultaneously lower-power and way more superpowered than anything you can pull off in Skyrim.  The fight sequences aren't too exciting, but it's a really nice change to disarm enemies with good timing (and then throw away the gun because seriously who needs guns) instead of blowing them away.  Of course you don't have to throw away those guns, I'm sure my playthrough would have been a lot easier if I wasn't playing pacifist, but it felt more natural that way.  Weird.It's your standard Prince of Persia jumping-puzzle fare, which means there's spots that can be really frustrating to get through, but that only caught me a couple times.  Checkpoints are pretty liberal, so getting stuck is always "Getting past this part is hard", not "great, I need to backtrack through half the level again".Other comments...well, it's always nice having games with female protagonists and no romantic subplots.  The game feels a little short, but it was worthwhile, it didn't feel tedious.  There's hidden collectables (like pretty much every Prince of Persia style game) but there's not a whole lot; completionists won't lose whole weeks of their life over it, thank God.  It doesn't have achievements, which is really annoying considering that the console versions did get them.  Despite the fact that it's a console port though, the controls still feel simple and natural.  Fascinating bold use of colors in the game, I liked it a lot aesthetically.So, yeah.  In summary, it has cool aesthetics, and it makes you feel like a superhero more than any superhero game.  Very worthwhile diversion that won't eat up a lot of time.

content:
Posted: June 21, 2014
												Few games give people a lot of freedom of movement or the feeling of fluidity as they transition from one area to the next. Mirror's Edge, on the other hand, makes it all effortless and smooth. No other game has made me feel quite as mobile and agile as controlling Faith as she moves across the rooftops.Faith can stop and fight if she really wants to, and she'll do alright at it. However, the game gives us a second and often wiser choice: run away. Faith moves faster and better than any other enemy in the game, so the cops can't catch her once she's past. As in Thief and Dishonoured, it's possible to play through with minimal combat, though it's arguably a lot easier to do in Mirror's Edge. This isn't a combat game at heart.I like games that try to do something different, and I especially like games that succeed. Mirror's Edge shows that a game can be all about movement, to the point that combat, though present, is largely unnecessary.

content:
Posted: August 29, 2015
  Feature Y/N/Rating   SLI Yes   Framerate Cap 120-144+ *   FOV 32-110+ *   Key Rebinding Yes   Options Minimal   Performance Good/Great * = Needs Basic Unreal Engine 3 Config File Tweak - See PCGamingWiki.com/wiki/Mirror's_EdgePC Port QualityIt's a UE3 game, which are usually great or only have small issues than can be fixed in the generic UE3 config files. Side note, in the bindings file where you add in Numpad binds for FOV changing, you can also add in various cheat, camera, and level-unlock commands. The in-game mapping is basic but definitely capable for the amount of inputs the game calls for. I've found the game to crash if you Alt-Tab, and the main menu isn't amazingly responsive, but other then that, the performance is great. You may need to rename one file to improve Physx performance though, details on the wiki above. The game feels great with mouse and keyboard, and it's extremely satisfying and comfortable with an FOV suited to your viewing angle. The game is just shy of 7 years old, but most of it's environments are astoundingly beautiful, especially in motion. It doesn't have that sheen and insane dynamic lighting effects that some brand new titles have, but I have no qualms about it's appearance even today. I'm very strict, and I have surprisingly few issues with the port, largely because of the games limited scope and it's engine.GameplayThere's honestly nothing like it. Certain games have used small parts of it's movement systems years after it's release, but none I'm aware of other than a small indie title or two have focused purely on it. There are some small frustrating sections involving guns, but they can largely be avoided. At it's core it's a navigation/exploration focused first person platforming game, and it's atmosphere is incredible. There are many sections with a calm and quiet ambiance that are a joy to experience, but simultaneously, it's really suited to speedrunning and it rewards memorizing the routes. You can even go further, learning shortcuts across a wide range of difficulty, and nailing them in one run is extremely satisfying. There are even modes suited to this, allowing you to run both entire levels and specified routes through various areas that often differ from what you might have seen through the game initially. Certain sections of the game, like the very last section of the game, are b-lined through under a time restriction with enemies, so it's great to be able to experiment and play in those areas without restrictions. Sadly, not ALL of the most interesting areas of the game were included within the time trial mode. If all else fails, you could toggle god mode with a hotkey, clear the enemies, and fool around from there. I do wish the game avoided combat scenarios entirely, and that there was a quick-save option to allow quick experimentation within levels.The cutscenes are of two types. 2D animations in a unique style, as well as small moments in first person that transition right from play. They are okay, but they are sometimes awkward and are the clearest example of the game's limited budget. I feel the game could have benefited instead from Half-Life style scenes where you remain largely in control. Similarly, I feel the game could have also benefited from some optional areas to explore, again in the style of Portal 2 and Half-Life. Forcing the player to look through desks for a key would be needless and annoying for speedrunning, but optional areas to explore and search through, possibly for some voiced exposition/thoughts from Faith, the player character.TLDR - SummaryDon't let my hours played fool you, this is one of my favorite games of all time. I played the game on both 360 and PS3 for hundreds of hours, and then again multiple times outside of steam over on origin. It's not brand spanking new, and could benefit from some more interesting modes as well as some additional convenience features, but the core gameplay is beyond satisfying and incredibly unique. I felt exposition was largely lacking and rarely memorable, the locations however will be familiar for a long time. A common issue with games this age and older, is a case of rose tinted glasses. The shocking thing here, is that for this game I've found the opposite to be true. The game now at 120FPS, maxed out with SweetFX is extremely easy to achieve in terms of hardware, and that combined with the switch to mouse and keyboard controls with a higher FOV, make the game far more beautiful, comfortable, and satisfying than I ever remember it being. As I said the cutscenes and certain combat sequences aren't great, but I've known that from the beginning.The game frequently goes on sale on both Steam and Origin, and has been in two Humble Bundles as well, and I completely recommend buying and playing it when it does. The sequel is set to release soon, and I hope more than anything that they can do the original justice. It looks promising thus-far.

												One of the only games in the genre, this first-person parkour game does something almost unique. The graphics are bright and blooming with futuristic white buildings which have aged well on the older game. The parkour can at times feel a bit clunky, but once you get the hang of it you'll be racing across rooftops easily, which is where the bulk of this game's fun is. This game is also a must-play for speedrunners, as I can easily imagine all kinds of little tricks you can do to shave off more and more time in-game.

content:
Posted: September 14, 2014
												Mirror's Edge is a first person running game developed by DICE. You play as Faith, a free runner. The story is set in a modern utopian society with a totalitarian government. Invasive surveillance is a part of life in this city and runners help exchange information between parties without getting caught.Gameplay is the most admirable aspect, its not perfect but its very innovative and first of its kind. I was skeptical of how the game is going on handle. I am glad that DICE persisted with the first person perspective because Mirror's Edge is very unique.Graphics are good enough, some of the views from the tall buildings are beautiful and vertigo inducing. During the frantic chase sequences when there is a real rush to escape, vision tends to get a little blurry by the edges when leapt over rooftops and I could feel my stomach lurch forward at times. Playing this on my 24 inch monitor at 1920x1200 at highest settings with PhysX enabled is real treat. On the flip side, Mirror's Edge can be frustrating in spite of DICE getting all the hard parts right. They made a game that handles free running extremely well. I never found the camera to be a problem and the controls on the PC are great. I loved the the chase sequences and getting the stunts right is not very difficult. The is hurt mainly by some intentional bad design choices - the scourge of all games. Weapons are extremely weak, it reminded me of Tomb Raider Legend and not in a good way - those of you who played it would know the reference, and melee combat is frustrating and unsatisfying. This only serves to break the momentum needlessly and seemed like an after thought. DICE have developed Battlefield games, so its not as if they are inexperienced in first person shooters, yet the gunplay in Mirror's Edge is very inadequate. I would recommend playing the game on Easy setting to avoid the frustration of combat.Also, the game is quite short. On Easy I finished the game in about 6 hours. For a free running game to be truly effective, it must have the feel of an open city where the gameplay is not restrictive. I can understand that at times this might be necessary, but throughout the game, you will be in a huge city, which you cannot explore and the path is very linear - just like an old platformer. + Visuals+ Brilliant soundtrack+ Decent story telling+ Some segments are truly breathtaking+ Tight controls- Very weak combat- Crappy 2D cut scenes- Short

content:
Posted: February 25, 2014
PresentationMirror's Edge is unique, fast and unforgiving, putting you in a strict governmentally-controlled city where the "Blues" are controlling everything and the only group standing between them and the total control of the city are the "Runners", highly trained and fast free runners that are doing their best to avoid the blues for as long as they can and live from the shadows, undisturbed by the oppression of the blues, which seemed to work just fine. You play as Faith, a young girl who was trained to become a runner after her mother died in what was the last attempt of revolution, and whose only relative that she cares about is her sister, a cop who was framed for the murder of the only man capable to make a chance, Robert Pope who was soon to become the new mayor of the city. She then starts a mission of clearing her name and finding the ones who were truly behind the assassination as it is not only about her sister going to jail, but also about the future of the city which now seemed to remain under totalitarian oppression for a long time. This game isn't your typical open-world adventure, mostly because it isn't exactly open world: you can always see the city and how big it truly is, but you are limited to the area where you current task is, simply because you will spend most of your time jumping from a rooftop to another, and reaching to a different direction than the one where your objective is, is impossible. This isn't a bad thing, as the game will automatically move you from one area to another as the story progresses and even with its limitations you can still choose which route to take, even though sometimes the obvious one is the only one available. The universe created for this game and the possibilities are enormous, however it never reaches its full potential; the campaign is indeed a powerful story about family and honesty, but the anime cutscenes between missions don't favour the plot at all, as they are merely dialogues between a few characters with some movement that most often feels out of place. The cast of characters is also impressive, but in the same way it feels disappointing as you never get to meet all of the runners and find more about their stories or the previous events and the conversations that you do have are just small talk without anything interesting to say that would affect your view of Mirror's Edge' universe.Rating: 7.5GameplayThe entire city is made to be your playground and so the game chooses to focus on just a few primary colours, with the white being predominant for almost anything around you, using red for objects that you may interact with and blue or green for secondary objects that are not necessarily a part of the free-running concept. Using this mechanic, the game manages to deliver a fast phased gameplay where the colours are your guiding instruments, but can sometimes become your disorientation tools as well as some objects such as stairs which will always be painted in red can be put on top of some cranes which will also be painted in red, making it hard to see where the stair is. Aside from those small issues that are isolated to certain areas only, the free running mechanic runs smoothly and the entire game takes no more than five buttons + directions to control, making it easy to move fast as the game originally intended. Aside from the free running, there are certain shooting sequences where you must disarm one of the opponents and use his weapon to kill the others, and even though those work just as smoothly, they are not the thing that makes this game shine, but thankfully some of them are optional as you can avoid certain encounter with the enemies pursuing you and those that are however mandatory will be over before you know it. Throughout the game you will use almost any combination of parkour manoeuvres, from wall jumps to flips, dodges and lots of jumping, and even though at first the entire thing will look hard to do at high speeds, once you get the hang of it you will amaze yourself with the tricks that you managed to pull off and a somehow impossible gap between building will suddenly become a piece of cake once you learn to use everything around you to your advantage. Aside from the free running that is exceptionally made, there is little to change the phase of the game, aside from turning a valve or pressing a button here and there in order to open a door and even though the hidden bags which act as the game's main and only collectible are a significant part of the game itself as you will be alerted by the game's logo on a wall when a bag is nearby, they will only distract you for a few seconds, and after that you're back to see where the story leads you.Rating: 8GraphicsMirror's Edge looks awesome without the smallest doubt and seeing the entire city from the rooftops is impressive, even though you can't access most of it, but for a short game that is meant to take you from one corner of the city to the next one the environments look pretty much the same wherever you go and that is mostly due to the heavy use of white and red to favour the gameplay and even thought it does look unique and amazing at first, seeing the same white and red everywhere you go will eventually make everything seem dull. The PhysX effects do a great job, making glass shatter in realistic ways and explosions or water effects look even more amazing, topping that off with the superb character design makes the game look beautiful wherever you go, no matter who you interact with.Rating: 8AudioThe game sounds as good as it looks, with effects realistic enough to make you feel each fall or wrong turn when you fail a jump and accidentally drop down a few meters or water splashes when you step into a puddle. The gun effects might not be as top notch as the ones you would see in a first person shooter, but they get the job done; the voice acting is decent, but aside from Faith you won't hear anything spectacular, and she doesn't even talk during the actual gameplay, only in cutscenes. The soundtrack is rhythmic with the action and always perfectly bonded with whatever is going on the screen, and the good part is that most of it will unlock as an extra once you finish the game so if you liked it you can listen to it how many times you want afterwards.Rating: 8ExtrasSadly, the entire campaign only takes around 5 hours to complete and even though you do have a time trial and a speed run mode, you only have the playgrounds from the campaign at your disposal, so you will eventually grow tired of running around the same tracks, but at least you have online and friends leaderboards, so you can brag about your scores.Rating: 6VerdictWith its minor flaws, Mirror's Edge is still a must play, especially for those in search of a unique, eye-view experience, but unfortunately the game will only last for a few hours and after that aside from the time trial and speed run modes that might keep you busy for a couple more hours at best, there is nothing else to do.Rating Overall: 7.5Check the full review and a lot more about Mirror's Edge at http://gamedragons.net/viewtopic.php?f=7&t=230

content:
Posted: February 27, 2014
												What happens when a underground style gets so popular that even a game is made using its unique style? Mirror's Edge happened. With this said, let's begin, shall we?Graphics: Oh my god, i forgot how i used to love how Mirror's Edge looked like. It had a different visual style, using more red, blue and white than any other color. That's because it fuses together with the universe of the game and give a better personification of who are the heroes and the villains. More than that, textures and overall presentation were pretty sweet. Using PhysicX to make all the details (Grass breaking, heavy footsteeps and some animations) even more detailed was a nice touch and let us experience a game that, even tough is linear and not really open world, gives to the player the sensation of freedom.Gameplay: Mirror's Edge is like Sonic in first person. You will run and jump, but it also haves a variation of the many challenges/puzzles that you will have to do so you can arrive at your mission objective. The game did a good job at keep motion and mobility of parkour at the same time and it's pretty realistic. No "you just din't survived this♥♥♥♥♥♥quot; falls and no "oh my god, my characther is so weak", it's all up for the player's capacity of thinking fast and making the right decision to either escape from the police or pass through one of the challenges that i mentioned above.Gunplay is quite okay and, since you don't use it so much (Except for the final part of the game), it's okay for what this game is. The mechanic of making the characther heavier while carrying guns was rather annoying. Why does a single pistol weights so much that i can't even make a straight, low, jump with it? Damn. But i guess it was to keep the focus of the game: Fighting with your own hands and making your way using only your parkous abilities. A bit forced, but okay for me.Slow motion helps a lot, even more because you can use it on quick time events, and damn, they are fast. I'm pretty sure that there were times that i pushed the defense button but my characther just kept dun goofing. Weird, but passable.Level Design: Really love. Exploring for secrets, doing time runs and just playing the game for the sake of doing it feels good. All the levels maintain both the interest of the player and variation, always showing new challenges and different ways to use your parkous abilities to solve all the problems that you will face. Sometimes the jumps looks almost impossible, but it's all about using what the game will give you. Sometimes the answer is right in front of you, but you just can't see it. And as i said, combining it with the graphics, it gives the sensation of freedom to the play and always make you think that you're playing a open world game. Even if it's linear, i can remember of 2-3 that i could've taken another path to get to the same place, and it was a nice touch. It could've been more used through the game, but that doesn't take the bright of the effort put in the level design itself.Soundtrack: Calm while not being seen and really rock hard when being chased or something is happening in the story side of the game. It always add something to the gameplay and it's pretty neat to hear. Based Lisa Miskovsky (Still Alive, credits song).Story: Even so people said that this was the low point of the game, for it was actually a pretty good CONCEPT of a plot. Mirror's Edge isn't a game that tries to have a lot of twists or a complicated storyline, but it does haves a good plot to follow and it's enjoyable for what it is. I think i liked it for the fact of the animated scenes making me think that i was watching an Anime or maybe because i think the whole thing of "Freedom To Spread Your Way Of Thinking" gives the player a lot to think about. Even tough Faith and her sister are pretty much the only characters that will shine to you (Aside from the main villain, that, being pretty serious now, i din't liked that much), there are other ones that can be explored in the sequel (Confirmed by EA) and may gives new ways of creating plot devices and sub-stories. The universe is like a hole: The more you dig it, more sand you will have outside of it. I really hope that, since the next game in the series seems to be a open world one, that the NPCs will, at least, have a conection with the first one characters (Or just let them be the first game chracters already). TL;DR - Story had an amazing potential, but it was okay for what the first game tried to be.Overall, Mirror's Edge is one of a few DICE and EA Games that make it into my "favorite games ever" list. Not even Battlefield 2 made it into this one (And it's a pretty awesome shooter IMO). I guess it's because of how this game tried to change the way of using FPS and explored the many possibilites of using parkour in your favor as a game developer. I really hope that the sequel keeps the shine that i still can see in this gem and will be as good as the first one.If you are waiting for the second game, being afraid of buying the first one, please, don't. Even tough i think you really don't need to play it for the story, there's a lot in this game to see and explore. Even i keep revisiting this game from time to time, always surprising myself with something that i haven't seen before.

content:
Posted: January 10, 2015
												Mirror's Edge ist ein simples wenn aber auch nicht ganz so leichtes Jump'n Run spiel.ERKLÄRUNG:In Mirro's Edge wird man in die Rolle der Runnerin Faith geschmissen. Am Anfang des Spieles wird dir die Aufgabe aufgetragen einen Hindernissparkour zu meister. Hört sich einfach an, ist es zu anfangs auch. Später werden die Level komplizierter, doch mehr dazu unter Gameplay. Jetzt werdet ihr euch denken: Aber was heißt das denn jetzt, Runner?Nun, die Runner sind eine der Zwei großen Gruppen in diesem Spiel. Dazu aber mehr im Storyabschnitt, welcher folgt.STORY:In Mirror's Edge befindet man sich in einer Stadt im Jahre 20XX. Diese Stadt wird (wie in de Story erklärt) bereits komplet t überwacht wird. Die meisten kommen damit klar, oder interessieren sich überhaupt nicht dafür. Die bereits gennanten Runner sind eine Gruppe die meistens im verdeckten Pakete etc. ausliefern. Die Polizei spielt hierbei natürlich auch eine Rolle. Denn die Polizei weiß von den Runner und wird natürlich alles erdenkliche probieren um euch im Spiel aufzuhalten.GAMEPLAY:Am Anfang vom Spiel wird man als erstes in einen Trainingskurs gesetzt weil die Hauptcharaktärin einen Unfall hatte.Hier lernt man zu Anfang viele verschiedene Gameplayelemete wie zum Beispiel: Wallrun, Abrollen (wird sehr wichtig im Verlauf des Spiels.) und andere auf Parkour bezogene Dinge. Die Steuerung ist nicht so schlimm wie manche behaupten und ich denke sogar ohne Gamepad besser.GRAFIK:Mirror's Edge benutzt einen Comic-Grafikstyle. Allgeimen sieht die Grafik aber ganz schön aus für das Jahr 2010FAZIT:Mirror's Edge ist ein sehr spannendes Spiel mit schöner Grafik, Soundtrack und mehr. Es lohnt sich wirklich für Fans von Parkour. Es hat so gut wie keine Bugs und läuft flüssig wenn man die PC anforderung erfüllt, oder überschreitet.Habt Spaß mit diesem Stück Software.

content:
Posted: January 19, 2016
												I wish there was a neutral 50/50 option. Instead, I'll have to choose one which does not fully represent my impressions.To me this games looks more like a proof of concept, a competent experiment, rather than a full-fledged game. Its mechanics are rather simple, but it does not make the game easy. It has a full-on story, which is somewhat grim in contrast to stunning vibrant visuals. Oh, the visuals... Mirror's Edge looks gorgeous even in 2016, to me at least. Use of colour is brilliant and artists surely knew what they were doing. Music is great too, by the way, and complements the action greatly.So why did I choose to not recommend this game?From a parkour simulator I expected a bit more flow, a bit more uninterrupted motion. Due to level design choices it's only possible(at least it was for me me) when you replay the levels you have beaten previously, which is frankly not the thing I'd like to do. But then again, first-person platforming is not as well developed of a genre.And lastly, combat. The game actively discourages you from engaging in unnecessary sombat, to the point of being unfair, like deleting all loose guns and removing the one you held in your hands upon loading a checkpoint(checkpoint placement could be better in places, too). But still, for some reason I used every opportunity to kill 'blues' that I could. To me it was much more fun than avoiding them, and it clearly wasn't the intended way to beat this game.Still, if are interested in such sort of game and the pros outweigh the cons - go for it. It's a competent product overall which you might enjoy far more than I did.

content:
Posted: March 25
												This review is a bit late because I thought I wrote it but I had only made my preliminary notes on it while playing the game and hadn't ACTUALLY written my review, because I'm an idiot.Sorry guyzAnywho, Mirror's Edge follows Faith Connors through a narrow strip of the City of Glas, a setting which looks like it would be a beautiful open world type area, BUT we didn't get that until 2016 whenever Catalyst came out. Which was meant to be a sequel then a prequel and now is.... Kind of a prequel kind of a reboot, people are pretty divided. The point is the series has kind of been in development hell.Bellyaching about that aside, the game has a decent storyline which is told through these cartoony cinematics. Which was really different than most other games that had come out in 2009. This is good. The game, however, tries to tell a deep story with a lot of edgy characters with shady pasts that we don't get any kind of background on. And while this could be accomplished with 2D styled animation, it.... just doesn't fit in with the tone of the game. This is not so good. I can see why some people enjoyed it, but it didn't sit well imo. Let's talk about gameplay. I hope you like moving forward and occasionally telling Faith to jump or dash, then getting angry whenever she DOESN'T do what you said. As far as difficulty goes, there isn't much difficulty that can be attributed to anything other than glitchy gameplay.  I feel like the game also didn't know what it wanted to be. One second, you're running in a straight line, and the next minute, you're at a standstill trying to either sneak around enemies or getting shot at. To me it didn't flow very well, it felt choppy, like the true essence of the game was being stifled by the combat or puzzle platforming sections. Motion isn't fluid, it's like a river that has been dammed up, it still flows, but the flow is choppy at best.  As far as the story goes, it is shallow. The one twist in the game (which has been spoiled for pretty much anyone with an internet connection) can be EASILY seen coming. I purposefully avoided content pertaining to this game because I had beem told there was one twist in the entire game, and it would be spoiled really easily, and I STILL saw it coming. And usually, you feel satisfied with a game's ending. The story gets wrapped up all nice and pretty unless the devs KNOW there will be a followup. Not here though. The end, without spoiling anything, sets up for a sequel that never comes. The story doesn't start to get good until the last few chapters of the game, and then none of the questions that arise gets an actual legitimate answer. And my last gripe... THE ENTIRE GAME GETS RETCONNED. "Oh but the devs wanted to go in a different direction." I hear you say. "But Pokemon Master 503, you loved Tomb Raider and it got retconned!" NO THESE ARE NOT THE SAME SCENARIOS. Tomb Raider got retconned by DIFFERENT COMPANIES. Also, most games that get retconned HAVE MORE THAN ONE GAME IN THE FUDGING SERIES.As far as bang for your buck goes, this game doesn't really give it to you. It's a game based on speed, with time trials for all the chapters and everything, but other than going forward a la Sonic the HedgeHog, the gameplay doesn't really vary all that much. Granted there wasn't much gameplay to vary.. Ten hours is all it took for me to gain 100% completion. And while this would be okay with, say, an indie game, this game was a AAA title, with huge marketting behind it at the time. If I'm not mistaken, it sold for full price back in '09, and to me 10 hours of gameplay would NOT have been worth the full price tag. It's not even worth the current $20 price tag to be completely honest. If you're gonna pick up the game, pick it up on sale.Verdict, go play Catalyst. It's ten billion times better despite what IGN said.

content:
Posted: January 31
												Mirror's Edge is a piece of art, but it isn't for me.  It plays like a very well-made indie game, and that's not so great for a AAA developer.The game has a very polished visual style, with lots of bright colors and good level composition.  There's something about it that reminds me of the Portal games.  Voice acting is passable, but after playing it you'll be hard put to say that there was even any music because it's so forgettable.  The story is... underdeveloped.  It's not bad, but it's short, predictable, and the Flash-player cutscene style contrasts too much with the visual design of the rest of the game.  The ending also sequel-baits pretty hard, so it loses points for that.  The parkour in the game, I have no doubt, was polished and maybe even revolutionary in 2008 when the game came out, but is now clunky and to some degree inconsistent compared to modern games like Dying Light which I have no doubt copied a great deal of their systems from Mirror's Edge.  When you're running around here, you feel heavy somehow, but I suppose that's just more realistic than other games with similar mechanics. There are three things that defeated my enjoyment of the parkour.  The first was a mostly garbage checkpoint system.  It isn't any secret that the game causes some degree of rage amongst players, but to me it ruined the flow a parkour game is supposed to have.  I would not have had a problem with this if %100 of my deaths were my fault, except...The second issue is that there are legitimate times when particular ledges or walls trip you up.  There are usually multiple causes for this.  In some cases, a degree of inches matters.  You jump too soon or at slightly the wrong angle, or without enough momentum you didn't know that you needed, and the game will screw you hardcore.  Sometimes there are spaces that you SHOULD be able to get around/onto, but it wasn't programmed into the game, resulting in you bouncing right off.  But, there were also a few times where the environmental design frankly just derped out with "false edges." Are the environments unnavigable?  No, of course not, many people have completed it just fine.  But you need to bend your expectations around the game's quirks more than you really should have to.  The third element that ruined the parkour for me is that it's all linear.  The game is on rails, and quite honestly that's a real shame for a game about climbing and freedom of movement.  There is exactly one way to proceed through the levels, and although I appreciated that you can hit Alt at any time to orient yourself on where you're trying to get to, this linearity greatly overshadowed my supposed freedom.  The combat is extremely basic, and you know, beyond the fact that the game included a way to induce bullet time because even it thinks that its own window for weapon disarms is too small, I don't expect a parkour game to have much more than is presented here.  My one gripe in this respect is that given how complicated the environments are, there are a lot of times when there's absolutely no way those pre-scripted enemies intercepted you that quickly.  It's great for keeping the pressure on the player, which is why they do it, but it's also fantastic at breaking immersion.  Even though I just♥♥♥♥♥♥all over the game, I don't hate it.  If you're still curious about it, go for it.  I'm just saying that there are reasons it goes on huge sales so frequently.

content:
Posted: December 29, 2015
												Rating: 8.1/10Overview:Mirror's Edge was developed by DICE in 2009. It is an action/adventure first-person shooter parkour game.The game is based around the  female protagonist “Faith” who is part of a group of couriers called “runners” who carry packages around the city. Using their parkour skills, they avoid police by running along rooftops, sliding down rails and ziplines, bashing through doors, and jumping off walls.Gameplay:I played this game using an Xbox 360 controller which synced all controls instantly. The controls and game feel like they were made for a controller. The movements are very fluid, the button setup is flawless, and it all feels natural in your hands.  Graphically, it is a masterpiece of its own.  It has a beautiful art style with graphics matching the time of the game’s release. The soundtrack matched the game very well; exciting and fast paced when it needed and slow melodies to soak in the beautiful cityscape.  The game itself was fun. It had its fair share of puzzles and fights that required the use of its multi-button parkour system. There were almost always multiple routes the any destination. The only downside to the style of gameplay was that at times it felt repetitive. It doesn’t give the desire to keep playing until the end, but still exciting enough to beat the game.Price: $4.99 during Winter sale. $19.99 regularly. Absolutely worth the price on sale. But I would still say the game is worth $15.Conclusion:A must play. This game is fun and exciting with a one of a kind style.  A controller is recommended. This is recommended for anyone who enjoys FPS, puzzles, or the idea of doing parkour and become a street ninja without actually risking their life.Price: 9 (on sale)Graphics: 8Story: 7Gameplay: 7Controls: 9Enjoyment: 8Concept: 8Music: 9

Posted: December 31, 2013
												DISCLAIMER: Don't pay full price.I feel like I will leave that disclaimer at the top of many other Recommendations from here until forever.While Mirror's Edge is a beautiful and fun game, it is not worth the full money either. Well, perhaps it is, depending on your interests. Call me a Scrooge, if you will.But I found the game terrifyingly short as I beat it in a few hours, and neither the time trials nor returning to the story for the collectibles really make me want to keep playing, so I find no replayability either. Hence, I believe it lacks enough to justify the full price tag.However, the game is definitely worth playing and it's very fun. The parkour style running is interestingly done and lends to puzzle-like rooms very well, often livening up the game instead of making you simply run down a hallway over and over. The combat isn't too great, but it's not really a combat-oriented game, though I did like that sewer section where you can snipe at the guys in the tunnels.As I said already, the game is also beautiful. Man, it may kill your machine if you don't have something new. I have a newer laptop which is able to handle quite a lot of gaming, actually, but full graphics on this game would make it churn heat like no other. It still ran beautifully, though, even with all of the settings maxed out, with the exception of a few places here and there which would lag the game into oblivion. Oddly enough, most of those sections didn't seem to have anything around that made sense with the lag, as I couldn't figure out why the game would die out in an empty hallway, for instance.In any case, if you've been interested in the game, certainly purchase it on sale. I never thought I'd play it and eventually I bit the bullet and got it. I'm glad I did.

Posted: January 16, 2015
												(WARNING: Deep and meaningful review incoming that may be long that only talks about the aesthetics of the game and NOT gameplay)It may have taken only a small while to complete (I've had it on the 360 years before I had it on Steam), but for a short game, this is now one of my all time favorites. Why you may ask? Is it the story? Not really. The Gameplay? Well, yes, it's nice and all. What the hell is it I hear you ask? Well, this game, this little gem in the gaming world is something I like to refer to as 'aesthetically pleasing'. The beauty of this game is something that's inspired me and gave me a new view on the world and life, but I won't bore you with what I believe in and all that. Take at look at the images on this game, see the colour schemes? That's right. There's only really ever 2-3 colours at a time most of the time. Everything is mostly white, but there are some positive colours as well. Like orange, green and blue. This use of colours just... relaxes me. The city in which this game takes place is unknown, no name. All there is to suggest where this city is, is a clock within the game that shows an American timezone, Seattle, to be more precise. This whole game, the way the world is presented makes me believe that there is a future without a gloomy outcome. I personally believe all cities should look like the one in this game. Even more so like how this very same city is shown in Mirror's Edge 2. In the 2nd game which isn't out until late 2015 to Spring 2016, the city looks way better and more like how I would want an ideal city to be like. It is so peaceful. It shows safety, order and peace. I'm not sure how to describe it. The city in this game is so... its just 'aesthetically pleasing'. The city shows progress and that humans can craft such wonderful things. Look at the trailer for the 2nd one: 


YouTube™ Video: Mirror's Edge 2 Trailer (HD) 

			Views: 1,565,157		

			Mirror's Edge 2 trailer (HD). Subscribe for every single full walkthrough on every major upcoming release and every single gaming trailer as soon as it's live: http://bit.ly/WTMIRO Every single E3...		

This is how I see the future (ignore the fighting scenese and all that). Focus on the music and visuals more. Most notably the 0:57 part and onwards. This. This is what I see as beauty. And with Mirror's Edge 1, you will get that! And hopefully the same with the second one. There is a character in this game called Miller. If you look at his uniform, look how classy it is! That attire is just... it matches the world so much! The guards uniforms too!Same goes for the music. The music is just... it does the city and game justice. It makes me see a brighter future. I don't know. I probably sound like a crack-head right now, but this game is just SO. DAMNED. BEAUTIFUL.The music is so relaxing and makes me think of a brighter future without fighting and whatnot. Well, that's the end. I'm sorry I didn't talk about gameplay, but that's not what I wanted to talk about. I'm sure others have JUST talked about the gameplay. Few have talked about the game as a form of... 'art'? Maybe 'art' is too much. Well, for others at least. I personally think this game is art in terms of visuals.Thanks for reading. Sorry for any spelling mistakes too. *bows like a boss as curtains fall and roses get thrown on the Steam stage*P.S. Back when DICE could make games and EA could publish them. Let's hope ('I' hope) they do a fantastic job on the second one! By the trailer, everything still feels like Mirror's Edge!
