												This game...this game....it's ok I suppose..............nah i'll explain why.PROS:Free running: When I heard about this I had thought that someone actually made a game that a lot of people would enjoy, well it kind of went everywhere on this.Characters: All of the characters you meet in Mirrors Edge are actually part of the story, not one of them feels really left out as far as I know.Story: The story felt pretty good, I didn't really seem to miss out on anything, it all made sense, atleast until the end though, I ended up forgetting or maybe not knowing why *Spoiler* Faith's sister was being dragged away by a bloody helicopter though.Fighting: The fighting in this game is a little simple but that's why I like it, it's either counter, punching, or GLACK GLACK GLACK GLACK with guns the whole time.Well that's all I can think of for pros...CONS:Free running: This feels a little glitchy at times, it works well yes but on the (I want to say skyscraper level) where you have to go through all of this construction part I ended up getting really glitched because Faith wouldn't grab onto some of the ledges or pipes to swing but when I did it another time she seemed to do it just fine.Sight Seeing Tour: This entire game isn't free roaming like I was hoping, it's just a f*%king sight seeing tour, it's way too linear, when I thought of free running I expected I don't know FREE ROAMING?!  All of those big and shiny buildings that looks just perfect for running on are basically just there to oogle and not to interact with, it's like a strip club.Fighting: This game doesn't know what it wants to do sometimes, sometimes it says to run away and others it says to kill them all, make up your mind Mirrors Edge it's either one or the other not both.Quick time events: This is kind of crowbared in you could say, you have to hit a button when a enemy tries to melee you, when you hit the button is when their gun turns red, but it's hard to get it right, the slow down is very useful but jesus christ does the slow down take forever to get out, and it's very very slow, why not just slow down a little bit that way it will still be challenging but it won't lose it's flow at the same time?Slow turning: What I mean by this is the slow head turning you have to do on ledges or pipes, yeah it's fine but seriously Faith TURN YOUR DAMN HEAD ALREADY.  It doesn't take 5 seconds to do that it takes half a second to.Red Vision: This was kind of annoying, if you got lost the red colored objects mean to use this, but sometimes there wasn't any AT ALL telling you where to go and it got annoying running around the place trying to find out what you had to do.Well that's all I can think of...the game gets a 6/10 for me, many things I was hoping for got destroyed but then again this is EA we are talking about, and they can't do anything too well.Is this game worth it as it sits? NO. Is it worth it on a sale? YES.

content:
Posted: December 31, 2013
												DISCLAIMER: Don't pay full price.I feel like I will leave that disclaimer at the top of many other Recommendations from here until forever.While Mirror's Edge is a beautiful and fun game, it is not worth the full money either. Well, perhaps it is, depending on your interests. Call me a Scrooge, if you will.But I found the game terrifyingly short as I beat it in a few hours, and neither the time trials nor returning to the story for the collectibles really make me want to keep playing, so I find no replayability either. Hence, I believe it lacks enough to justify the full price tag.However, the game is definitely worth playing and it's very fun. The parkour style running is interestingly done and lends to puzzle-like rooms very well, often livening up the game instead of making you simply run down a hallway over and over. The combat isn't too great, but it's not really a combat-oriented game, though I did like that sewer section where you can snipe at the guys in the tunnels.As I said already, the game is also beautiful. Man, it may kill your machine if you don't have something new. I have a newer laptop which is able to handle quite a lot of gaming, actually, but full graphics on this game would make it churn heat like no other. It still ran beautifully, though, even with all of the settings maxed out, with the exception of a few places here and there which would lag the game into oblivion. Oddly enough, most of those sections didn't seem to have anything around that made sense with the lag, as I couldn't figure out why the game would die out in an empty hallway, for instance.In any case, if you've been interested in the game, certainly purchase it on sale. I never thought I'd play it and eventually I bit the bullet and got it. I'm glad I did.

Posted: October 28, 2014
												NOTE: This game isn't for everyone, but it stands strong for me. I got Mirror's edge on the PS3 a few years back and fell in love. I just recently bought the game on steam. Don't judge the amount of time I played the game because I've mastered every level. REVIEW: This game has a sense of endless running, most free run games do. But this one has the smoothest freerunning and is different in every aspect. You have advanced control over Faith and her actions. You can quick turn, strafe, slide, roll, duck, jump, vault, vault jump, climb, wall run, wall climb, and shimmy. This is all from a first person view, which makes the game stand out. Back to the actions, when you combine all of these in a flawless motion you feel unstoppable. You play as Faith, a female runner, that wants to stop a corrupt government and save her sister. As a runner, you see the world in primary colors, red being your guide through out the game. To everyone you seem like an outcast, but all you're doing is stopping the government from taking away peoples freedom. The game lacks interesting characters besides Faith, and the story isn't the most memorable. At first you will find the game hard and very frustrating, but the more you play it the more you use the free running to your advantage. From there, you will find new paths and ways to navigate the environment. The combat isn't the best, The counters are bad, the punching isn't satisfying, and the gun play is useless. The wall run kicks, disarms, and jump kick and slides are the best part of the combat. The campaign is short too. Besides those minor flaws, the game is fun and worth getting if on a sale. It's a solid 8/10 for me.

content:
Posted: October 6, 2014
												Mirror's Edge, 5 years from its PC release still looks pretty impressive, even by todays standards. The game world is gorgeous and makes me feel pretty chill (when I'm not in the midst of a fighting sequence). The controls are simple, clean and easy to grasp, and the level design is creative. I especially enjoyed how puzzles could have multiple routes to their solutions, and how the route to the end point of a level wasn't immediately obvious because of this. There is also a rather nice soundtrack to accompany the game, and it fits the environment well. The story unfolds well enough, though for me the story took the back seat to the gameplay experience. The free running style, the jumping and the problem solving involved in completing levels was very satisfying. This isn't to say it was a bad story at all, it engaged me just fine, but it was perhaps one of the less strong aspects of the game. The game wasn't particularly long, but I feel this may work in its favour. There is the risk of challenges becoming frustratingly difficult/repetitive, especially when there isn't a particularly impressive story to drive it. I feel it ended at just the right time and the ending was executed well.Overall, I found Mirror's Edge to be a challenging, visually impressive game whose key selling point is the game mechanics. The parkour system is pretty good especially for it's time, and it just feels fun when you're running and jumping and executing the sequences. If Mirror's Edge 2 takes these elements forward and builds on them using todays technology, it should hopefully be a very good game, much like its predecessor.

content:
Posted: October 6, 2014
												Mirror's Edge, 5 years from its PC release still looks pretty impressive, even by todays standards. The game world is gorgeous and makes me feel pretty chill (when I'm not in the midst of a fighting sequence). The controls are simple, clean and easy to grasp, and the level design is creative. I especially enjoyed how puzzles could have multiple routes to their solutions, and how the route to the end point of a level wasn't immediately obvious because of this. There is also a rather nice soundtrack to accompany the game, and it fits the environment well. The story unfolds well enough, though for me the story took the back seat to the gameplay experience. The free running style, the jumping and the problem solving involved in completing levels was very satisfying. This isn't to say it was a bad story at all, it engaged me just fine, but it was perhaps one of the less strong aspects of the game. The game wasn't particularly long, but I feel this may work in its favour. There is the risk of challenges becoming frustratingly difficult/repetitive, especially when there isn't a particularly impressive story to drive it. I feel it ended at just the right time and the ending was executed well.Overall, I found Mirror's Edge to be a challenging, visually impressive game whose key selling point is the game mechanics. The parkour system is pretty good especially for it's time, and it just feels fun when you're running and jumping and executing the sequences. If Mirror's Edge 2 takes these elements forward and builds on them using todays technology, it should hopefully be a very good game, much like its predecessor.

content:
Posted: July 4, 2016
												Mirror's Edge is essentially a trial-and-error game for me. The Reaction Time feature works wonders! However, although the game features moves heavily inspired by parkour, I felt that the only overwhelming stunts were the box vaults and the wallrunning. As a first-person point-of-view game, seeing the vaults being performed were much less appealing.The main character could have been more relatable if it weren't for the fragmented revelations of her past. I know that this is not that kind of story, but the motivations for each character, although explicitly stated, passes by too quickly without giving the player a chance to be immersed in the game. The game also promised melee combat yet most of the enemy NPCs wield guns and are VERY TRIGGER HAPPY. I see no reason to shoot an unarmed assailant even at point-blank. However, if the game is made such that the player should avoid most conlicts at all costs by just freerunning, then the selling point of this game is half-achieved. The game is actually short minus the parkour fails! I expect more from the next installment!PS. The sound effects as she falls are gut-wrenching. As an acrophobic, I approve.

												Mirrors Edge is a game, which is a bit different from all the other FPS...though...i wouldn't even call it FPS...more like First-Person-Parcour-Simulation-with-bits-of-Combat.So, if you like the idea of Parcour and running through levels, running along walls, jumping over obstacles or sliding below them, give this game a try.If not, then don't even bother continue reading.You're taking over the Role of Faith, a so called Runner (which is sort of a courier which brings informations or items to their clients).As already said, you will run and jump and slide through the levels in First-Person View, which is actually quite fun and pretty well executed.It does feel pretty good to do wallruns, jumps and slides and try to get the proper timing.Though it has it's flaws, the story is rather thin, the combat (which isn't mandatory, you can outrun them or punch them to the floor in most cases) can be pretty frustrating and checkpoints are sometimes set a bit stupid (though most of the time pretty fair).It's definitely worth a look, especially because it does things different and it was definitely a risk doing such a game, and for me this needs to be rewarded, even though it's nowhere near perfect.

content:
Posted: December 10, 2014
												What you're reading this for:       + The game looks as good or better than the images above, which were surely what brough you to check it out. Trust me, it's gorgeous, it's everything you thought it'd be.       + It has deep, rewarding, visceral, insanely well thought movement system.       + Amazing soundtrack and art design.     -/+ You'll restart a single checkpoint over and over which ruins the feel of flowy momentum of running around. There's going to be one jump in ever level that'll test your patience. But you'll end up liking the way you hone your skill by repeating it.       - Very short single player.        - The animated cutscenes seem forced in and depart from the overall style of the game.       - Trial and error.This is my favorite game. Of all the ones I've played, this is my favorite. It feels very physical to run around and you actually gain momentum the longer the run-up to a jump is. Not only that, but DICE didn't even just pitch an idea and fill the rest of the 12 hours of the campaign with whatever... oh no no no. Ever level and stage is carefully though through with design and graphics and location of the enemies. Faith is a slender, quick cat and the game makes an excellent job of making you feel like one yourself, but never powerful, always weak, oportunistic, wathcing for where the soldiers are. Except when they're aware of exactly where you are and you are trying to grab the tiny pipe on the ledge while avoiding contact with buckshot.I think this game was an amazing premise brought down slightly by some marketing representative who insisted that market research demanded shooting things.

Posted: December 3, 2013
												The first time I played Mirrors Edge was on the 360.  And let me tell you, this is a fantastic game.  Set in the future, it's about a girl called "Faith" who is what is called a "runner" they are basiclly some sort of resistance group against a corrupted Goverment. Without spoiling too much, Someone gets framed and it's up to Faith to figure out what is really going on.What I really liked about this game was the fact that unlike most dystopican future settings, it's not set in a dreary dark enviroment. But rather a very beautiful looking city. But as you play more and more, you realize that beauty has almost an ominous feel to it. And to me, that's even more creepy. Something that appears to be beautiful, but deep down has a darker secret.  The gameplay is very uniqe, in a sense you focus more on jumping to other buildings,over obstacles, ect, and you try to avoid combat as much as possible. I have a bit of a bias for games that try to use other methods other than combat.(Like metal gear for example, where running and gunning gets you punished.) but this game really does do it well. I know that a sequel(or rather prequel) is coming out soon. And I hope it will as good as the original. I reccomend it.

content:
Posted: September 8, 2016
												A game that relies heavily on a good flow to be enjoyable but does every little thing in it's power to ruin that flow. It took me roughly seven years, a disc, a Steam purchase, and six or so installs/attempts of Mirror's Edge to finally put it in the completed pile. I had glimmers of fun each attempt but always ran into a rough area of gunplay or something else that gave me a window to go astray and play something else. A bundle purchase some time ago gave it a new opportunity to catch my eyes on the Steam platform but still it rotted in my backlog. Until yesterday. After years of hearing good things and people's fond memories I decided I would beat it. I did. And I did not enjoy most of the experience and was consistently reminded why I always walked away all those times over the years. After a night to sleep on it and make sure cooler heads prevailed, the verdict remained the same; I did not enjoy Mirror's Edge at all. This game features the absolute worst FPS gunplay I have ever experienced. This is not hyperbole. The worst. A "bullet time" skill that is too slow and a disarming skill that is entirely clunky do very little to alleviate the problems. There is also some frustrating platforming but that I would easily forgive. I only bring it up because it and the bad gunplay mean you die a lot. Which is only an issue due to very oddly picked respawn checkpoints. Some are spaced too far from the last, some put you too close to a ledge to generate the speed required to make a jump without backtracking, some put you back before a, hopefully, short scripted sequence or annoying script line, some put you behind slow opening doors again and again, etc etc. I'd have to say at least 30 minutes of my 4.3 hours was repeating stuff from my hundreds of failures. Yes, the game can take a mere 4 hours to conquer. Toss in config setup, bad dragging cutscenes, LONG elevator rides, lots of vent crawling... That 4.3 hours gets really really short. That ended up a relief for me though, I did enjoy that it ended sooner rather than later. The story is the definition of average which I normally wouldn't complain about in a game but man, the universe they created was decently fascinating! So it was a stark contrast of this unique world and this downright boring story. The stories on newsreel monitors in those long elevator rides were by far the most interesting lore that was offered up.It is a beautiful game. Visually stunning, even all these years later. The city is crisp, clean, and unique. The platforming gameplay can feel downright amazing too. When you string together jumps and wall runs, it just feels right. The other thing is that it doesn't even need the fast pace to feel good. There were more methodical puzzle-like sections that with a little polish would've been wholly satisfying. But, following every brief moment of these fun things are abrupt, painful, interruptions to ruin things. Visually stunning game, suddenly cutscenes for an ordinary story with atrocious unfitting animation. Five minutes of free running filled amazing gameplay, interrupted by a section of that gunplay or some obtuse obstacle sequence. Methodical puzzle, interrupted by a poorly implemented ledge and shoddy checkpoint placement. It never stayed fun for a long enough period of time for me to forgive it's shortcomings. Its hard to recommend against a consensus "cult classic" and I fully grasp why people have raved about this game all these years. But the fact of the matter is the flow was interrupted far too regularly for me. And, again for me, the gunplay implementation was egregious and plain unforgivable. I would never recommend the game at any price. I didn't have fun. "Faith the trains!! ... Take the trains!"

content:
Posted: December 13, 2015
												I seriously wanted to like it. It has an iconic art style and there's nothing wrong with running and jumping and an occasional kick in a baddie's face.But for some reason the devs thought that rubbing a jump fail or weapon grab fail (and you'll have 100s of those) in our noses would be a good idea. When you fail you'll have to endure a fall to death with horrible bone break and squishy wet noises in the end. Thats kinda ok once or twice but believe me it gets tedious. And that's the best outcome.In some cases you can't even fall to your death and yet you know that you've failed (because you haven't escaped the guards). In that case you'll have to let the guards kill you. You might ask "but can't I just go back to the previous save point?" No you can't. You have to let yourself fall to death. When that doesn't work you have to let the guards shoot you down. And even for that, sometimes you have to climb a long ladder because the guards are too stupid to reach you otherwise.Seriously, dear devs, this kind of game design stopped being good around 1989.Additionally one might mention that putting puzzles (finding a non-trivial way in a building) and pressure (guards rushing in) together results in frustration. It breaks immersion when you solve the puzzle by just dying and respawning and trying again. This alone wouldn't break the game but it is a point.Difficulty is ok if the player has control. XCOM can be very difficult but there the player has control. Here too many things (wall runs come to mind) are far too random. There difficulty turns to frustration.As I said, I wanted to like it but it's impossible. I also thought about recommending it only for its art style but I think it's necessary to discourage this kind of game system design.If you are looking for something where immersion isn't broken all the time, that also has a very good art style and actually likable characters and a likeable story, try Remember Me.

Posted: July 8, 2016
												I really wanted to like this game. I've heard great things about the story and the engine has a lot of potential. Unfortunately the level design and gameplay are some of the worst I have ever seen, completely ruining what might have otherwise been a good game. There is little to no indication of where you should go (and no indication at all of why in most cases), so that randomly hurling yourself into space a few times until you pick a direction which doesn't kill you is the primary feature of play. This might be okay if you had time to scout around and figure out your route but every level (as far as I have played) has hostiles forcing you to keep moving at most times. You seem to need to identify (by, as far as I can figure out, trial and error) the right route for each section and follow that exactly, ruining the illusion of an open world which the engine gives.I understand that some people are probably happy with trial and error game play, random seeming action with little or  in-game explanation or real clue as to what is going on, being content to learn routes and try for their best time on them, but I am not one of them. I only spent £2.50 on this nonsense and I feel cheated, I can only hope that I can get my money's worth from non-story play since, as I said, the engine itself seems very good.

content:
Posted: April 20
												This first-person platformer game is disappointing. At first glance it appeared to offer interesting gameplay based on parkour, as well as nice artwork, but the implementation leaves much to be desired. Despite the apparent "open world" environment, levels are very linear. Yes, the player character runs on rooftops and inside large buildings in a big city, but the doors, windows, gates, vents etc. are blocked, locked, or just unbreakable, except for a specific path which the player has to find, often while being shot at. There are pipes, crates, planks, and other objects in the environment, but player can't move or otherwise use them to create new paths. There are armed enemies and the player has ability to fight, but combat system is subpar. And yet for some reason the story has the player character frequently go directly into the midst of said armed enemies, particularly in the last few chapters, making the combat system more conspicuously annoying. The lacklustre plot doesn't help either. Would have been better if it has actual "open world" environment, better combat system, and perhaps ability to bypass confrontations altogether (e.g. by sneaking around enemies or creating distractions). Overall, after completing it, I feel that while this game may be interesting when it was first released, it isn't a good use of time and money today.

Posted: January 7
												I understand that this game was released in 2008. It holds up graphically to this day, and the game looks great once you iron out the performance issues with physX. However, the combat is absolutely horrendous, even for 2008. You have to either memorize an INSANELY small window where you can melee an enemy safely and take his gun, or use the slow motion which is clunky and ruins the immersion. Once you have a gun, it handles horribly and your movement speed is reduced to a crawl (unless you have the pea-shooter of a handgun). The level design is pretty bad as well. Too many times I found myself stuck in a building or something trying to find the exit. This game would have greatly benefitted from a radar system or a map, as your "runner vision" can only work if you are already close to your destination. The actual parkour mechanics are wonderful though, and it is really fun to play once you get up to speed. It is a shame that the game's had such glaring issues because the core gameplay is really fun.

content:
Posted: June 15, 2015
												EDIT: In case you can't see it, I currently have 19 hours in this game, mostly in offline mode.     Mirror's Edge, I'm sure, is going to stay one of my all time favorite games. The graphics are beautiful, the soundtrack is relaxing, and the parkour is very fluid. This is the game I play when I get frustrated with CS:GO (I'm not the best). It does have its faults however. It will require you to pick up a fallen enemy's firearm every so often, and the gunplay is less than desireable, which is surprising coming from the creators of Battlefield (DICE). Aside from the poor gunplay, the levels sometimes incorporate live, die, repeat, Super Mario Bros-esque jumps that make the game feel almost unfair, but when you finally do make it (usually by utilizing some aspect of the environment that was previously overlooked), the rush of victory and accomplishment feels great.     The game makes you play through it on easy or normal difficulty the first time, which means Runner Vision is enabled. Runner Vision highlights different objects that can be used to navigate to your destination, which I find can be immersion breaking. Hard mode is unlocked after your first playthrough. It increases the combat difficulty and has Runner Vision permanently disabled.     I recommend this game to everyone especially when it goes on sale for $5. You have no reason to pass this up. The story isn't memorable, but the relaxing, detailed atmosphere and simple, fluid parkour controls make this game a must have.

content:
Posted: January 26, 2015
												Mirrors Freaking Edge. I game that combines combat with swift parkour and movement. A game with a solid soundtrack and spectacular graphics. Mirrors Edge appears more superb then most first person shooting games out on the market BUT IT'S NOT. The movement of the parkour is accurate and the foot and hand gestures match the pace of your character. Even the way Faith moved her finger was a indicaton that this games parkour perspective is realistic. Very realistic. This platformer has astonishing views, great use of color and a great concept but of course there's a glitch in the matrix. The concept is intriging at first indeed..but after quite sometime you stop caring for the story. You would think the plot would be major, involving a world crisis or a fatal disaster but you're only saving your sister.... your sister, that is most likely the most minor plot I've known.The character's aren't enjoyable since the writers hardly know anything about character development. Faiths emotions stay the same throughtout the whole game. You would assume she would become more hostile or lose hope but nooopppe. Mirrors Edge also gives you different areas to roam. Instead of running on a platform with 1 pole in the first chapter, you get to run on a platform with 2 poles this time. Imagine running into up coming traffic, jumping past traffic lights and vehicles. That would be more enjoyable. The fighting between you and the enemies is outstanding since you can steal their weapons and use them as your own but the shooting itself is too bleak and pointless. The shooting mechanic is useless since you have the oppurtunity to outrun enemies. (Always) and the shooting is one of the worst I have seen in years. This game was shaped into a paradise but a tropical storm knocked it on it's a**. 4.9/10

												Everyone I know seems to absolutely LOVE this game to death.Lemme get one thing straight: This game sucks in a lot of categories. Lemme list them from worst to best.Level design:The level design sucks in this game. Half the time I have no hint of an idea where I should be going, and even with runne r vision on, am left just to sprint around and desperately try to find a way to continue the game. It is just garbage. 4.5/10Difficulty:This game is oddly too difficult. I haven't even managed to make it through the halfpoint of this game, and I've been playing for what... 6 hours? Yeah. 6/10Parkour mechanics:The moving mechanics are... okay. At the right time they are actually very fun. However, they are broken to hell. Jumping from pipe to pipe is very difficult at times when it shouldn't be, and even just jumping to a higher position can be almost impossible. I've remapped the keyboard controls to fit what I think actually works, but it still is just a steaming hot pile of poop. 5.5/10Story:The story is decent. The voice acting in the cutscenes really lacks, I think. It just seems too forced and poorly written. "You can't just keep living on the edge! At some point, you'll have to jump!" Yeah. Really amazing writing. 6.5/10Life:By life I basically mean the normal populace things going on in the background. They're pretty good for a 2008 game, but they still really lack in some parts. The cars can sometimes not render properly, making them shine bright like they're being hit by light while they're clearly under a shadow. There are also way to few people. In a city as big as the one in Mirror's Edge, the city should be bustling with people! 7/10Total:5.8/10

Posted: December 17, 2012
												I recently beat Mirrors Edge (in about 6 hours of gameplay)The game is unlike any other, which you'll find out as you're jumping around actually avoiding enemies. You don't run into fights like in most games nowadays, you die too easily. You can take out one enemy easily, but they always move in two or more. If you're able to knock out or kill an enemy with your kickass martial arts skills you can pick up his gun, but you only have the magazine that is currently in it. The gunfights aren't exactly interesting, as its not a shooting game, but sometimes I found them necessary because I couldn't get around the enemies in that particular level. Of course the focus of the game is hardcore parkour essentially, you feel superhuman as you run across walls and jump across buildings. One bad step and you can find yourself plummetting toward the ground in a stomach churning fall ending with a sickening crack of bones and a splat. The cutscenes aren't interesting, they use an animation style that literally makes you feel like you're watching an esurance commercial. Honestly I would be sucked into the game, having a lot of fun when a cutscene reared its ugly head, and I didn't feel like playing anymore.Overall, the graphics are nice, the gameplay is fresh but sometimes repetetive, the story is generic and uninteresting, and the game is moderately hard to run.7 / 10

content:
Posted: March 19, 2016
												I would like to recommend this game on discount like i bought it. I did expect more of a kind of adventure or action rpg not sure why. But i wasnt too disappointed when it turned out to be a parcour fps game in the end. I wish there was a bit more nuance to the voting when writing a preview cause this game would have needed one. As overall i am not disappoint by the game but there are several things that were either missing or could have been done better. pro: - good graphics for the time it was published (around 2010)- nice flow if you find a good path that gets your speed going- not too easy, even when using the hint to the next objective often- female bad♥♥♥♥♥lead character (nice for a change)- interface simple and controls are sufficent for most stuff ingame- hints and runners vision help a lot  cons:- combat, i really wish you could completly skip the fighting part. But if you dont want to overly frustrate yourself you have to fight at some points in the game. Faith just isnt made for fighting full armor riot cops, so it kinda seems dumb when she swing bare handed at a full gear cop shooting her with a mp. The jump kicks dont do much and neve will knock out someone instant, same goes for the slide kicks. The whole thing feels so clunky and would be impossible to do if not for her amazing self healing powers so i took one cop out and hide around the corner waiting to heal back up. The fights could have been so much better if you could fully avoid them (sneaky beaky like) or just combine it with some form of martial arts like matrix or other games have shown.   - pathing, the game flow seldom felt like a smooth parcours like to me. Maybe its better when you know the levels in and out but when a game fails on one of its core mechanics it sucks. The rooftop chases and runs are usually done better but as soon as you enter a building it turned into a wild guessing game. Sometimes i just jumped every wall and rail to look if it would net me some kind of clue where to go next, this was a really bad break of the flow for me. Even f'---- mario can do better wall jumps than this girl. Things get worse when you are presented with a room full of policemen shooting at you while you are ducking behind a van and try to figure out how to reach that vent up above.  So i multiple times tried different paths just to get gunned down. In the end i had to clear the room (again with lame clunky fighting) just to have a moment to think about the layout. This whole thing could have been done so much better, if the developers want to make us believe that every building is filled with vents, pipes and edges to dangle on, why not take it a step further and make all the surrounding climbable or able to interact with. - story/atmosphere, story could have used a bit more pep apart from the standard ways. You are trying to survive in an authotarian city but barely feel the threat. Why not run through a crowd of people? Why are all the building empty but these obnixious cops? How do the cops always find you even if you escaped through different vents and underground facilities, as soon as you pop up, they are already waiting, is this girl wired? This was the biggest let down for me, a bit more life a bit more people and interaction. The only other persons apart from cops apear in cut scenes. Just take a hint out of Assasins Creed, disappear in a crowd, police will just notice you if you behave suspiciously.Just to get this clear, the game was ok, and worth the discounted price, but overall i never got too engaged with it as the cons are just too glaring and i hate when i play something and feel like dumb kid standing around with question marks all over my head. The game should almost never force you to do that. Its a different thing to repeat a sequence over and over again cause you know what went wrong, but this games lets you repeat some parts again and again not even knowing IF you are doing the right thing in the first place.

content:
Posted: January 26, 2015
												Mirrors Freaking Edge. I game that combines combat with swift parkour and movement. A game with a solid soundtrack and spectacular graphics. Mirrors Edge appears more superb then most first person shooting games out on the market BUT IT'S NOT. The movement of the parkour is accurate and the foot and hand gestures match the pace of your character. Even the way Faith moved her finger was a indicaton that this games parkour perspective is realistic. Very realistic. This platformer has astonishing views, great use of color and a great concept but of course there's a glitch in the matrix. The concept is intriging at first indeed..but after quite sometime you stop caring for the story. You would think the plot would be major, involving a world crisis or a fatal disaster but you're only saving your sister.... your sister, that is most likely the most minor plot I've known.The character's aren't enjoyable since the writers hardly know anything about character development. Faiths emotions stay the same throughtout the whole game. You would assume she would become more hostile or lose hope but nooopppe. Mirrors Edge also gives you different areas to roam. Instead of running on a platform with 1 pole in the first chapter, you get to run on a platform with 2 poles this time. Imagine running into up coming traffic, jumping past traffic lights and vehicles. That would be more enjoyable. The fighting between you and the enemies is outstanding since you can steal their weapons and use them as your own but the shooting itself is too bleak and pointless. The shooting mechanic is useless since you have the oppurtunity to outrun enemies. (Always) and the shooting is one of the worst I have seen in years. This game was shaped into a paradise but a tropical storm knocked it on it's a**. 4.9/10

content:
Posted: June 15, 2015
												EDIT: In case you can't see it, I currently have 19 hours in this game, mostly in offline mode.     Mirror's Edge, I'm sure, is going to stay one of my all time favorite games. The graphics are beautiful, the soundtrack is relaxing, and the parkour is very fluid. This is the game I play when I get frustrated with CS:GO (I'm not the best). It does have its faults however. It will require you to pick up a fallen enemy's firearm every so often, and the gunplay is less than desireable, which is surprising coming from the creators of Battlefield (DICE). Aside from the poor gunplay, the levels sometimes incorporate live, die, repeat, Super Mario Bros-esque jumps that make the game feel almost unfair, but when you finally do make it (usually by utilizing some aspect of the environment that was previously overlooked), the rush of victory and accomplishment feels great.     The game makes you play through it on easy or normal difficulty the first time, which means Runner Vision is enabled. Runner Vision highlights different objects that can be used to navigate to your destination, which I find can be immersion breaking. Hard mode is unlocked after your first playthrough. It increases the combat difficulty and has Runner Vision permanently disabled.     I recommend this game to everyone especially when it goes on sale for $5. You have no reason to pass this up. The story isn't memorable, but the relaxing, detailed atmosphere and simple, fluid parkour controls make this game a must have.

Product received for free
												So, let me preface this by saying that games with the kind of mechanics that Mirror's Edge uses are not my typical kind of games. However, I saw this in my friend's library and decided to give it a go. I'll be overly cliche in my review by just listing a few pros and cons along with my personal opinions as to why I gave this a thumb's down. Pros:Great parkour mechanicsBeautiful graphicsDecent voice actingDecent storyCons:Rather difficult if not used to these types of gamesDoesn't always give you a cut and dry path (which is fine, but difficult when limited to where you can parkour)Combat is choppy (although hardcore players will tell you it's fine tuned)Looking at the pros, it's obvious that the graphics, story, and voice acting are well done. The parkour itself, it terms of mechanics and overall gameplay, is a lot of fun to play and master. However, a quick glance at the cons draws my attention. The fact that every mission has an inexplicable amount of cops chasing you, while shooting, takes away from what I believe to be the core of the game. I want to parkour around the city, leaping from building to building. If this game was a puzzle game, where you had to figure out how to maneuver around rooftops, making difficult jumps, the game would be phenomenal. I found myself dying several times from missing jumps. Unfortunately, if I had to throw out a guess, out of my 30-40 deaths (I told you, not my type of game), around 25-30 are from dying to cops shooting me. I want the game to allow me to showoff my parkour skills (which the races are great at doing). I did not, however, sign up to play a shooting game. Now, I understand that it's an entirely different element and difficulty level, having to dodge shooting cops. However, it made the game FAR less enjoyable when I knew I was able to make the jump, but couldn't avoid the cop that kept killing me. If you're into the adrenaline rush, quick thinking time lapses of games like this, then this game is your bread and butter. However, with the cops, and shooting, it's far less enjoyable on my end. I don't think it's a bad game, and I plan on finishing it. But I paused mid-mission so I could write this review, because if I die one more time to a cop, I'm going to break something.

content:
Posted: December 30, 2014
												Mirrors Edge is a first person shooter unlike anyother, a game that rewards the player for avoiding combat and taking advantage of the fluid parkour to dodge their foes. It leaves room for the player to decide how they want to play, if they want to take the moral highground and avoid as many casualties as possible, or if they want to get their hands on one of their enemies firearms and blast their way through each mission. The art style of this game is also something that ties in perfectly with the play style, the sharp contrast of the white buildings with neon indoors and the hidden poverty that lurks in the backalleys. Although as much as this game is great it is not without its flaws, the storyline can often be confusing to follow and the missions are somewhat linear limiting the player to how much they can take advantage of the fluid movement in the game. All in all I highly recommend this game for anyone that needs a breath of fresh air from their standard shoot 'em ups.

content:
Posted: June 15, 2015
												EDIT: In case you can't see it, I currently have 19 hours in this game, mostly in offline mode.     Mirror's Edge, I'm sure, is going to stay one of my all time favorite games. The graphics are beautiful, the soundtrack is relaxing, and the parkour is very fluid. This is the game I play when I get frustrated with CS:GO (I'm not the best). It does have its faults however. It will require you to pick up a fallen enemy's firearm every so often, and the gunplay is less than desireable, which is surprising coming from the creators of Battlefield (DICE). Aside from the poor gunplay, the levels sometimes incorporate live, die, repeat, Super Mario Bros-esque jumps that make the game feel almost unfair, but when you finally do make it (usually by utilizing some aspect of the environment that was previously overlooked), the rush of victory and accomplishment feels great.     The game makes you play through it on easy or normal difficulty the first time, which means Runner Vision is enabled. Runner Vision highlights different objects that can be used to navigate to your destination, which I find can be immersion breaking. Hard mode is unlocked after your first playthrough. It increases the combat difficulty and has Runner Vision permanently disabled.     I recommend this game to everyone especially when it goes on sale for $5. You have no reason to pass this up. The story isn't memorable, but the relaxing, detailed atmosphere and simple, fluid parkour controls make this game a must have.

												EDIT:I wrote this review in about 5 minutes of fast typing, which isn't enough to express how much I LOVE THIS GAME! It is the best gaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaame in existance, and I think you should buy it to support ME2, or even just give it a play, as this game is EXTREMELY underrated________________________________________________________________Mirror's Edge was such an interesting game and still stands out from the crowd in 2014, even with the release of Mirror's Edge 2 sometime soon. From momentum and wallturning and wall-grabbing your way through the city to prove your sister's innocence leads you from a financial district to The Shard, in which you start from the bottom, leave and come back in and get to the top, kind of like if you go to The Shard in real life. Anyway, this game was so underated for its style which is even incorporated into Dying Light, a Zombie Survival Parkour game, where the parkour reflects Mirror's Edge to the point where Mirror's Edge could finally get the recognition it deserves. I have played about 7 hours I think by now, and I have played about 50 Hours on the PS3 version. Unless I like it, I don't spend that much time on linear, story based games. The only exception I can think of here is The Last of Us. The combat of Mirror's Edge is where this game fails to deliver though. The parkour makes up for the dreadful combat and countering. You can use weapons but you only have until the ammo depletes (which is only one clip) and Mirror's Edge 2 looked promising and I will buy it... for its parkour. I couldn't give a s*** about the story and I f***ing hate DICE and EA working together. I'll call them... DICEEA - Digital Illusions CE AB EA because the gameplay will 'focus more on combat'. WHY!? Mirror's Edge is about parkour not combat and because different people are making the sequel, the have NO IDEA what to do so they focus the game on combat over parkour because in my opinion, DICE give out orders to their workers of 'if you don't know what to do, involve guns. because we love guns and WE WANT GUNS!!!!!!!!!!!!!' so... yeah. I think that Mirror's Edge 2 should be bought in a sale of either 100% OFF! or 200% OFF! But knowing EA, I think this sale on Origin would be '0% OFF!' On the plus side, Mirror's Edge doesn't have any DLC. Shocking, I know because it is made by EA. Oh wait... not on Steam. On the Xbox 360 and PS3 versions, the Pure Time Trials are a thing that I own. However... for some reason, it 'isn't compatable with the Steam version' and my theory for this is that EA found that most game copies were bought on PC rather than PS3 and Xbox 360 versions and so that if people will buy the PS3 or Xbox 360 versions and the Pure Time Trials to get more money. Classic EA People, Classic EA...PunsKeep the FaithLeap of FaithNo running gags(More for me to remember soon!)
